output: Mr President, Mr President, Madam Vice-President, the Commission gives the impression of acting like a distracted pupil who runs after lost time before returning his copy.
Of course, the social package exists, but it is incomplete and can only be regarded as a step towards taking social issues into account by the Commission.

The President of the Commission has not taken account of the warning given by the citizens of France, the Netherlands and Ireland, which would unfortunately have been the same elsewhere in the event of a popular vote.
These votes are a reminder of the order.
If Europeans want more Europe, it is to build a social project and not just to adopt more technical directives.
The regulation of the internal market is certainly necessary, but it is far from essential.
The 2009 programme, like the previous ones, will go beyond the subject.
Citizens do not expect the Commission to merely complete or even simplify legislation.
They expect the Commission to meet the task assigned to it by the Treaties, the locomotive, the Union's idea box.
It is not enough for its President to be wise and silent behind the President of the Council.
We expect the Commission to act as a key actor in reflecting on the nature of the social project we need.
But what is the company's project in this program?
The 2009 programme does not contain serious errors, but it is not the programme in which our fellow citizens need to be involved.
Mr President, it will be up to the new College to take up its responsibilities.
I only hope that he will be less deaf to the calls of the peoples than he is today.
Mr President, first of all a question to the Council.

The guidelines for the high-level conference on Georgia, which had been proposed by the French Presidency, and how the current Presidency of the Union intends to defend the territorial integrity of Georgia, while a country recognizes two separatist regions, Abkhazia and South Ossetia.
It is a pity that Mr Barroso is not here because, in his speech, he was not convincing, perhaps because he himself is not convinced by the proposals he has made to us.
I think the financial and economic situation is much more serious than he described.
Even today, I think those who follow the Internet see very well that the stock markets continue to collapse despite the interventions.

It is really for me the collapse of the current system, a completely obsolete system, the system that has brought about bankruptcy, that has brought about a land being totally exploited and stifled by greenhouse gas emissions, that has led to poor development in the South and that has led to poor development in our cities.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, the current financial crisis shows that when the problem is global, global action is needed.
And this is especially true in the field of agriculture or in the field of food.
That is why we have created, in particular, the World Trade Organization, on which we agree, which is trying to have globalised rules.

It happens that it does not work quite as we would like, because we are faced with the following problem: we have to reconcile two things: the necessary free trade, on which everyone agrees, but the protections, which are just as necessary.
And the protection of national economies or agriculture does not mean protectionism.
To do this, the path we have taken for 60 years, since the GATT, is an unbalanced path that goes from the reduction of customs duties to their abolition.
It so happens that technically, the reduction in customs duties
It's quite difficult to prove a whole series of mathematical formulas, the South Korean formula, the European formula or the most well-known formula, the Swiss formula.
It doesn't really work because a product isn't unitary.
It is composed of many elements with very different rules of origin and technically reducing customs duties is not as simple as we think.
So we are in a technical impasse and we are trying politically, through negotiations, to get out of that impasse.
But it turns out that technologically, scientists have invented a new customs technology, the deductible customs technology, deductible by the exporter on the economy of the importing state.
In practice, this deductible customs duty becomes a customs credit equal to the amount of customs duty borne by the exporter in the importing country.
This three-character customs credit is reimbursable, negotiable and reimbursable.
It is refundable when the exporter goes to buy from the importer, he can deduct the customs duty he has borne.

It is negotiable because if the exporting company, which has supported 100 of customs duties, has nothing to buy from the importer, it negotiates it without customs credit on the stock exchange or in the bank.
And it is beneficial if we want to help developing countries, the importer, to offer a customs credit higher than the customs duty.
Well, with this technique, we create an international trade currency whose monetary mass is equal to the amount of existing customs duties.
For example, the European Union would offer 13 billion euros in international currency in the commercial field.

Mr President, the Russian-Georgian conflict and the financial crisis have given the European Union the opportunity to establish itself on the world stage as a full-fledged and first-class political actor.
Thanks to your determination, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Europe has succeeded in uniting and finding coordinated, effective and rapid answers.
In the face of crises, Europe proves that it exists and demonstrates its added value.
In the case of immigration, for example, each for himself was no longer a season.
The adoption by the European Council of the Pact on Immigration and Asylum, initiated by the French Presidency, is a considerable step forward.
On the fight against climate change, Europe must set concrete targets and show its way to its global partners.

You have already spoken on this subject, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, but we want this agreement to be as balanced as possible, because it must take account of the economic situation of our countries, which is currently very unstable.
But also to ask ourselves the question of the type of development we will choose for the future.
To meet the challenges ahead, the European Union needs the Treaty of Lisbon more than ever.
We understand the concerns of our Irish friends, but the status quo is not an option.
Ireland must propose a solution to us at the European Council in December, and many of us are asking for it.
In recent weeks we have proudly seen a strong political Europe united in adversity, determined in the face of its partners, listening on the international stage.
We want this new European mentality to become the rule and to endure.
The Treaty of Lisbon is the best solution we have to achieve this.
Madam President, Mr Minister, I was in Tbilisi when President Sarkozy came to negotiate the peace plan, and of course I pay tribute to him for acting quickly and stopping this war.
But this war is a bit of a failure for us, we have been frightened for 14 years, we have watched in silence the escalation of provocations in the separatist regions.

This war has certainly awakened Europe by placing it before its responsibilities, but the fire continues to burn in the Caucasus and we must do everything we can to resolve the frozen conflicts for the security of all of Europe.
I am also aware of the divisions, Mr Minister, between the European countries on Georgia's entry into NATO, and I am personally against it.
I will make a proposal to you, I will ask the European Union to propose the status of neutrality for these countries of the Caucasus.
Only the status of neutrality will be able to ease tensions with Russia and permanently prevent this subregion from further conflict.
This statute will ensure the security of these young democracies and contribute to our own.

Mr President, Commissioner, Mr Minister, in the last three days we have had the European Development Days, where the food crisis, which is seriously affecting the poorest countries and the poorest countries, has been extensively discussed.
All the speeches stressed the absolute need for developing countries to develop their own agriculture by making optimal use of their land and natural resources.

By the way, the lyrical outbursts of those who called yesterday and today for the reduction of state intervention and public spending, for the liberalization of all Asian countries, for the privatization and relegation of agriculture.
This almost prehistoric activity, this front-runner in favour of massive public investment in agricultural production and food sovereignty, all of this had something both cocky and scandalous.
The future of agriculture in developing countries is directly related to the debate we are having today.

Unfortunately, I do not feel that this CAP health balance, initiated before the paroxysm of hunger riots and disastrous market disorders, takes account of the situation of the peasants of the South and draws all the consequences of the serious ecological, social, economic and financial crises we are experiencing today.

I therefore deeply regret that the strong relationship between northern and southern agriculture is so little addressed, both in the Commission's proposals and in Parliament's report, and that the questioning of the promised billion euros shows how far the road still lies.
Mr President, the report we are voting on tomorrow marks the end of a year of work and negotiations on the future of the common agricultural policy and our farmers.
It was on 20 November last year that Mrs Fischer Boel came to make her proposals on the health balance sheet.
After the Lutz Goebbels progress report, here is the Capula Santo report on the Commission's proposal.
We must congratulate our two colleagues on their excellent work.
The European Parliament's Committee on Agriculture has been able to stand firm in the face of the Commission's proposals, which we have considered far too liberal.
I will remain vigilant with regard to the milk sector and in particular the measures preceding the abandonment of quotas.

I am thinking in particular of the mountain milk producers, who must not be the poor parents of this reform, and we must be careful not to leave them behind, because they will need to be supported more than others.
I do not want to play the role of Cassandre, but how can we imagine the French dairy industry grouped together in a single region?
It is therefore with goodwill that I welcome the proposal to set up a milk fund, which is to assess the increase in dairy quotas from 2010 onwards according to market developments.

Mr President, the calculation of the progressive modulation made by the Committee on Agriculture seems to me to be correct and would allow us to strengthen the development of territories, rural areas and to preserve biodiversity in a sustainable way.
I also welcome the clarification of eco-conditionality, the implementation of which has so far been a real headache for farmers.

I also want us to keep the amount of the tobacco fund which allows us to keep our small farms in Europe, as well as a non-negligible workforce in a region where nothing else is exploitable and which allows us to avoid imported products.
Finally, Mr Minister, we have greatly appreciated your commitment throughout these negotiations.
You have shown a great deal of patience and determination, and you have not counted your time without fail.
It was a real pleasure to work with you.
You have been very effective with us.
I know we can count on
Mr President, first of all I would like to thank you for the work you have done and for the conclusions and guidelines proposed by the CAP health balance sheet and the report by Mr Cabulos Santos.
Agriculture is indeed an economic sector which cannot respond to the simple signals of the market.
Its activity has an impact, of course, on food self-sufficiency, but it is also, as we have seen too often, on territories and employment.
The removal of market instruments would be a serious blow to our agriculture.
Decoupling, for example, is a real difficulty for some livestock farming areas, dairy cows and sheep, and I am pleased to have heard Mrs Fischer Boel speak on this issue earlier.
Moreover, it is clear that strict adherence to historical references would put a huge brake on any possibility of reform.
However, I still believe that the question of the second pillar of the CAP is an essential one because rural areas need to rely on agricultural activity to develop employment in the rural world.
So we have to think about this second-pillar problem without, of course, amputating the first.
Since Minister Jouillet is leaving us, I think this Parliament should thank him.
He was one of the most assiduous ministers we have ever known.
I wish him good luck.

Madam President, if I voted in favour of the Perisch report on the integration of the OCEAN 20 into the single OCEAN, I must say death to the soul, because I believe that this single OCEAN is not a simplification and does not increase transparency.
It will make life more complicated for the viticulture industry and for the whole viticulture industry.
Last night, the Commissioner tried to reassure us.
I hope that the Commission will take the floor and that, above all, the profession will still be adequately represented in the advisory committees, as has been the case since the first WTO.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen,
Mr President, Mr Minister, Mr Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, our group enthusiastically supports the draft Small Business Act which the Commission presented to us last June.

Of course, since the 2000s, initiatives have been taken in the direction of SMEs, and I am thinking in particular of the excellent work of our colleague Dominique Vlasto on the SME Charter, initiatives which have been appreciated but considered insufficient because they too often remained in the state of wishful thinking.
Today, we have to go further.
The serious economic crisis that our countries are going through and whose consequences are particularly worrying for SMEs invites us to do so if necessary.
In this respect, the Small Business Act is part of a new, resolutely voluntary approach.
In a few weeks' time we shall be examining Mrs Herzog's report on the Commission's communication, but today, through the oral question, we wished to call the Council into question.

Mr Minister, we have taken a keen interest in the conclusions adopted yesterday by the Competitiveness Council and we would like to know whether the European Council of 11 and 12 December will take a decision on this matter.
It will convey its conclusions well and will give a strong impetus to the rapid transposition of the great guiding principle of small first into the regulatory framework of the Member States.
We want the Council to commit itself to the principle of the action plan annexed, accompanied by concrete measures.
In this respect, and in the short time I have left, I will emphasize three areas in which we need compelling impulses.
Impact studies, which should be systematic and monitored regularly, with the European Parliament's control of the state of application of the Small Business Act in the Member States.
access to public markets
The Code of Good Conduct has no binding scope. Together, we must be more imaginative, more inventive and propose concrete, adapted measures that really open up access to these markets for SMEs.
Finally, access to finance, more indispensable than ever in the current context.
Your proposals are good, Mr Minister, and they must also include support for the offer.
There is an emergency.
Thank you for assuring us of the Council's will.

Mr President, Mr Minister, Mr Commissioner, we all know that SMEs are the backbone of the European Union, since they employ more than 70% of the European Union's workforce and represent 99% of European companies.

But as has already been said, these millions of small and mediumsized enterprises are now worried and threatened by the financial crisis because it degrades the purchasing power and confidence of households, affects order books.
It is therefore the treasury of SMEs that is at risk and it is therefore necessary to ensure that banks have effective access to the financing necessary for the continuation of their operations.
This is all at stake in the conclusions of the Competitiveness Council on 1 December, which the Minister spoke about, and in the recovery plan approved by the European Finance Ministers.
Making the needs of SMEs a permanent political priority for the Union is essential, and I wanted to welcome the action plan in favour of the Small Business Act for Europe.
It translates into the will to ensure the effective application of the guiding principle of giving priority to small businesses first, i.e. European SMEs.
However, as the Commissioner has said and as we all say, the Council must really engage with the other institutions.
In order for this principle to be put into effect now, we must go beyond the declaration and implement it in all European policies and programmes.
However, we can say that this action plan is a real response to the urgency of the situation.
And I would like to congratulate the French Presidency of the Union on the voluntarism which has made it possible to translate the intentions into action quickly.

Mr President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, I give my full support to the rapporteur, who defends the position which was ours at first reading, a position rejected by the governments of the Member States.
It was urgent to bring our legislation on guard duty into line with the jurisprudence of the Court of Justice.
The CERCA report provides balanced and protective responses for employees.
All the guard time is counted as working time.
Compensatory rest shall be granted immediately after the period of service.
This is a matter of common sense to ensure decent working conditions, particularly for medical professions.
But the reform of the Working Time Directive also gives us the opportunity to advance our European social law by abolishing individual opt-outs.
The CERCAS report seizes this opportunity and proposes a gradual abolition of any possibility of waiver of the maximum legal duration of working time.
We have to face reality.
It is a joke to say that the employee is on an equal footing with his employer and can refuse what is offered to him.
Ladies and gentlemen, we must make it clear to the governments of the Member States that the text they wish to impose on us is unacceptable.

In the concert of praise which will certainly be heard by the French Government as early as tomorrow, it seems to me necessary to take an interest above all in the employees who will be called upon to work more and more without really having a choice, and this, like all those who will be asked to work on Sunday in France.
It is obviously to open up this possibility that the French Government has changed its view on individual opt-outs in the Council.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let us listen to the employees and try to respond to their appeal if we do not want the negative votes of the French, Dutch and Irish referendums to be followed by many others, calling into question a European Union which would give them the feeling of not dealing with their daily problems.
Mr President, it was a very nice French Presidency.
There were very few dissenting voices to disagree.
The 27 went beyond their differences to reach a series of exemplary decisions.
On the energy and climate package, Europe is taking a first step, and in this, this first step is immense.
It now has the means to assume its environmental responsibility without, however, sacrificing its economy.
It can now take the lead in this area to lead the other continents on the path to sustainable development.
Moreover, Ireland is proposing a scenario to get out of its isolation.
Our Irish friends will once again be voting on the Treaty of Lisbon with all the cards in hand, since virtually all the other members will have made their final decisions.
The current crises show us that the Union needs the best institutional tools to be effective more than ever.
The European Council adopted a massive and coordinated economic recovery plan based on long-term productive investment and targeted support for the hardest-hit industrial sectors.
President Sarkozy has raised the problem of reducing certain VAT rates and I fully share his view.
Let us hope that the Ministers of Economy and Finance will reach an agreement in March which seemed impossible to the Heads of State and Government last weekend.
The challenges facing Europeans give the Union the opportunity to show itself in their eyes more united, more responsive and more concerned about protecting them.
We are grateful to the French Presidency for having breathed new life into this dynamic.
We, like Nicolas Sarkozy, do not want to see yesterday's councils, which ended at 4 a.m. to negotiate three coconuts, again.
In the last six months, Europe has changed its mindset, its scope and its credibility.
We must thank the French Presidency for this, and we are well aware that it is not entirely foreign to us, Mr President.
The situation in Gaza is known to everyone.
What we are discussing here in Parliament is natural.

But we are asking the Security Council to take a position, we are asking the institutions to take a position, the European Union to take a position, and we in Parliament are discussing and we do not want to take a position.

I think that, despite the urgency of the situation in Gaza, it is extremely important that this Parliament decides and says exactly what it wants to do to stop the massacres taking place in the Middle East at the moment.
I find it unacceptable that this Parliament does not have the courage and the lucidity to vote on a resolution after our debate.
That is why our group calls for the decision of the Conference of Presidents to be revised and for the debate to be concluded.
We have to deal with the situation in Gaza by a resolution which will demonstrate the clear and firm position of this Parliament, with a majority, to stop the massacres in Gaza.

We want a resolution, we must be aware that we have a political responsibility in the face of what is happening, and this political responsibility cannot simply be a discussion, it must be a resolution that clearly says what we want and what we denounce.
Mr President, Commissioner, more than ever, the proposal for a directive which Parliament is about to vote on gives me a very mixed feeling.
It is true that the rapporteur, Mr Klins, has been working for years and has negotiated with talent, particularly during the trilogue.

It is also true that the directive has made a number of significant advances towards better functioning of the internal market, collective management of financial assets and is therefore welcomed by the European investment fund industry.
It remains that the debates and discussions in the Council and Parliament have never been entirely free, since the results were known in advance.
In principle, there is nothing to be said about the fact that the passport is completely defended, but it is also necessary to ensure that the introduction of the passport for management companies
It is accompanied by the necessary guarantees, in particular in the area of fund supervision, as it leads to a dissociation of functions beyond borders.
However, I regret to note that the system in place is not only complex but also subject to divergent interpretations.
It is very likely that it will soon run into practical difficulties which will harm European industry in terms of export funds, particularly to third countries.
I have taken note of the fact that my position is minor, but I do not feel uncomfortable.
In normal times, I would have been tempted to say that only the practice will make it possible to draw definitive conclusions on the matter and therefore to determine
Who is right between those who rely on the adaptability of market actors and those who are cautious?
It is not excluded that success is at an end, but on the other hand, nothing guarantees it either.
However, the very recent news, in particular the Madoff scandal and its implications for the financial assets collective management industry, is not meant to reassure us.
Skepticism is followed by my anxiety.
The investment fund industry will not be spared by the financial crisis, as we can see from now on.
It may be necessary to make fundamental changes in this context of crisis.

The fact that in this context of deep crisis we are making choices which dilute the responsibilities of the actors or which presuppose perfect cooperation between control authorities can really be considered incongruous.
I tell you, as I think, this directive is also the result of a period of revolution before the crisis.
It is marked by a certain recklessness.
Indeed, the financial system is going through a lasting and fundamental crisis of confidence, and entire sections of its architecture need to be reconsidered.
Let us not forget the primary function of the OPCMs is to protect the investor by diversifying risks and establishing strict rules.
This autism does not bode well, which is why I will abstain, even if I have signed the compromise amendments negotiated with the Council.
Given the circumstances, the improvements made seem to me to have been of little importance in the face of the questions of principle which I have just explained.

Mr President, although the regulation on the report on animals has been in force since January 2007, it seems that the Member States have not been systematically regulated by providing, as they were asked to do, annual reports.
Therefore, a comprehensive analysis remains random, since many elements are missing as regards the means put in place to carry out inspections.
As a member of the Animal Welfare Association and a member of the Intergroup on Animal Welfare, I am particularly concerned about this.
The associations have been fighting desperately for decades to finally introduce directives in this area in 2007, where we see that the Member States show a certain laxity.
I would even dare to say a certain bad will, because, as we know, the implementation of controls and inspections is absolutely not insurmountable.
We know the slaughterhouses, we know the breeding grounds, we know the livestock transit routes, so what's the problem?

I believe that it is important, in our time, when public opinion is increasingly made aware, rightly, by the animal condition, whether it is at the level of livestock, slaughter or transport conditions, that the States respect these feelings.

And since I have the floor, I would like to add, with regard to transport, that it would be essential to look at and take into account, regardless of the duration of transport, local climatic conditions.
Indeed, a multi-hour transport in the Netherlands in the spring is nothing compared to the same transport time in the middle of summer in a country like Greece.
Shouldn't we impose night transport in these last cases?
I thank you for considering this proposal in the future.

Madam President, I am glad that it was a British man, our colleague Mr Parrish, who submitted this text, just as the Romanian soldiers two thousand years ago did well to go to Britain and bring amphorae of olive oil and wine.
But then we'll have to draw two conclusions.

It is not very reasonable, symbolically, to put the Food Agency in Helsinki, and it is not reasonable for the European Commission not to go back on the following points: first, to restore aid to the amended, then to stop the
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has already made a number of proposals to the Council and the European Parliament on this subject.
I suggest that our Commissioner, our President, Mr Barroso, organise a grand banquet in Portugal with sheep cheese and wine.
Mr President, we have all been fighting for the closure of Guantanamo and we have all welcomed President Obama's decision to close this prison of shame.
Today, the question of welcoming Guantanamo detainees should not be a question for us.
As Europeans, loyal to our values of defending the rights of the individual, we must take responsibility, because it is our duty to welcome these former prisoners.
We have been able to read, and I am addressing the Council here, we have been able to read in the press that some Member States were not very warm for this welcome.
I would like to make a real appeal to the Council, and in particular to the Member States who are reluctant to accept these prisoners on their territory.

And I will tell you, ladies and gentlemen, that the worst thing would be for the goodwill caused by the closure of Guant√°namo to be overshadowed by what we would not have answered here when we called for Europe.

This is important because the European animal feed sector is one of the most important sectors of agriculture, both in terms of production, as it represents half of the European Union's agricultural production of 120 million tonnes, and in terms of turnover of some EUR 50 billion.
The European Union has 5 million farmers and 60 million pets.

In the past, the European Union had to deal with a number of health crises, which means that today we need to be more vigilant about transparency in order to meet the expectations of farmers, but also of consumers.

The provisions in this report have the advantage of representing a minimum cost for industries and a major benefit for consumers, who are increasingly attentive to the quality of the products they buy.
The adoption of this report will help to limit risks by ensuring better product quality, better control, better traceability and greater information for the farmer and, ultimately, for the consumer.
Today, with the increase in international trade, it is more than imperative to strengthen all preventive measures so that the food crises we have experienced in the past are no longer repeated.

Mr President, this report succeeds in reconciling the right to information, while strictly defining the nutritional elements that must necessarily appear on labels, and the right to intellectual property, which is so important for preserving the competitiveness of our industries.

I believe that manufacturers must indeed be obliged to notify immediately the use of any new raw materials entering the composition of animal feed in order to ensure transparency and facilitate the control carried out by the competent authorities.
The inclusion of an emergency procedure to introduce a new dangerous substance on the list of prohibited substances seems to me to be absolutely essential.

Similarly, giving the farmer the opportunity to question the competent national authority or the European Commission in case of doubt on a dishonest allegation makes it possible to better monitor the system and protect the customer while preserving the loyalty of commercial transactions.

I would therefore like to give my full support to this excellent report, because experience shows that regulation on the labelling of food for animals, with priority given to quality, transparency, traceability and control, is the best guarantee for preventing new sanitary crises in Europe.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is certainly not Europe, much less its High Representative for Foreign Affairs Javier Solana, former Secretary-General of NATO, who can play the role of mediator between Israel and the Palestinians.
At the very least, they are called upon to finance the reconstruction of the Gaza Strip, as they are doing today for Kosovo, Lebanon or Afghanistan.
The Americans and the Israelis are bombing, the Europeans are financing the reconstruction.
This is the distribution of tasks between allies.
But it should be the thieves who pay.
Egypt is at the heart of the peace talks on a prolonged ceasefire with Hamas.

But the challenge is formidable as the new Israeli government, under pressure from the third man, Lieberman, leader of a democratically accepted far-right, risks seeing its task as particularly complicated in this negotiation.
Indeed, Netanyahu, who is portrayed as the future prime minister, has always opposed a truce with Hamas.
Another difficulty is that the Palestinian Authority of Mahmoud Abbas has become in West Jordan a kind of international protectorate whose legitimacy has greatly diminished among the population.
The expansion of Israeli colonies, which has never ceased since 1967, makes the creation of a Palestinian state in the West Bank particularly delicate.
Today, the bullet is in the Israeli camp, but do the falcons in both camps accept this truce of God that both parties are demanding without giving themselves the means?
Let me add a reflection on the reintegration of France into the NATO military structure, which will be discussed in the Vatanen report.
This reintegration will entail severe obligations for France.
Indeed, we are reintegrating NATO, even though the Cold War has been over for 90 years.
Sarkozy seems to have forgotten the fall of the Berlin Wall and Russia's return to the ranks of the free nations.
Should the logic of the blocs be strengthened at the time of the multipolarization and the rise to power of emerging countries, including on the military level?
In addition, France's accession to the integrated structure will force it to strengthen its contingent in Afghanistan, where it already has 3 men on the ground.
With what budget will it finance, when its defence budget will fall below 2 of GDP and more than 30 regiments will be abolished?
Paradoxically, we are going to increase our budgetary contribution to integrate NATO and at the same time reduce our military presence in Africa.
European defence, dear to President Sarkozy, will therefore be a pillar of the Atlantic Alliance.
It was enough to read the Treaty of Lisbon and its additional protocols to be convinced of this.
Whether it is foreign policy or common security, the European way is an impasse which will only lead to a alignment on the Americans and their allies.
It is this logic of erasure that we reject in the name of sovereignty and national independence, relying in particular on our autonomous nuclear deterrent force.
Madam President, I congratulate our three rapporteurs on this rather remarkable synthesis of the current state of our common foreign and security policy.

Mr President, Mr High Representative, you know better than anyone that Europe is expected today on the world stage to take its place in the world stage by its economic and demographic power and the richness of its democratic and humanistic values.

I am forced to note that, despite the regular willingness of more than two thirds of our European citizens, as you have said, some progress has been made, I agree with you, over the past ten years, but I am forced to note that this Europe still does not exist.
If a recent illustration were needed, its erasure in the solution of the new drama in the Middle East would be there to demonstrate it.
There was, and still is, a need for a European presence in Gaza to play an active role in both helping the survival of the populations and rebuilding the
In the fight against arms smuggling, which had made it possible to turn this territory into a base for launching rockets of all calibers.
Despite the good words spoken in Charm el-Sheikh and Jerusalem, nothing has yet been done about it.

Mr President, I repeat a question which has already been asked on the occasion of the Lebanese crisis: when, Mr High Representative, can we hope for the deployment of a European fleet in the Mediterranean, as we have put one in the face of piracy?
We have the means.
Will we ever have the will?
Mr Commissioner, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Parliament's decision to accept the urgency requested by the Council for the next budget is a welcome one.
The handling of this matter was unanimous, both in the Committee on Fisheries last week and this morning, here in plenary.
We are all aware of the need for the European Union to honour the commitments made in Marrakech last November by the competent international committee, the ICCAT.
It is a question of putting into effect the recommendations adopted by this organisation in order to curb the persistent phenomenon of overfishing of red tuna in the Mediterranean.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the difficulties faced by the fishing industry in the eastern Atlantic and in the Mediterranean, and whether he is aware of the serious dangers to the future of the species, and therefore to the fishing industry itself.
Two of our colleagues from the Committee on Fisheries, Mrs Fraga and Mr Romeva i Rueda, were present in Marrakech and will speak about it in this debate.

I would like to recall the importance which our committee attaches to this matter, which puts at stake the main dimensions of the common fisheries policy, namely the management of fisheries resources.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the difficulties faced by the Member States in implementing the directive, and if he is aware of the difficulties faced by the Member States in implementing the directive.
This characteristic file therefore constitutes a test, in our view, of the credibility of this common fisheries policy.
For this reason, there was obviously no question of the new recovery plan being put in place without the consultation of the European Parliament.
I am therefore pleased that the Commission has finally chosen the only legally and politically acceptable way of implementing the

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the recommendations of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Protection, namely those of a proposal for a regulation in good and proper form on the basis of Article 37 of the Treaty.

The transposition into Community law of commitments made by the Commission on behalf of the European Union in regional fisheries organisations is not an unusual operation and we insist that it be carried out under the democratic control of our institution.

In substance, I welcome the various measures proposed, which, although binding on our operators, are up to the challenge, and I stress that the most important are the measures proposed by the Commission.
The important measures are certainly those which concern and will concern control, so it is true that without control no reconstruction plan can be effective.
I therefore thank you, Commissioner, for this proposal and I invite you to show as much determination as possible.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Council has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so, what is the Commission's position on this matter?
Madam President, Commissioner, I regret that the Council and the Commission have not yet taken the initiative of defining territorial cohesion in concrete terms.
The French Presidency has tried, and I would like to welcome, this initiative.
Our Parliament continues to insist that this objective be applicable as soon as the Treaty of Lisbon enters into force and that its outlines be specified as soon as possible.

I hope, as Mr Van Nistelrooij's excellent report does, that territorial cohesion will become the legal basis guaranteeing the harmonious development of all the territories of the Union and making it possible to make the best use of the characteristics of each European region.
It is essential to better coordinate Community policies in order to maximise the impact of interventions on the ground.
Territorial cohesion is not intended to target only regions with permanent disabilities.
Nevertheless, it must be committed to the polycentric development of the European Union as a whole, taking into account the characteristics of each territory while preserving its diversity.
This new concept seems to me to be relevant for the consideration of the outermost regions in order to ensure sustainable and balanced growth.

In this respect, I thank the rapporteur for having taken up in his compromise amendments my demands on the specific challenges facing the outermost regions in terms of accessibility and competitiveness, which are an essential element of territorial cohesion.
In reading the Commission's recent communication entitled 'Europe is an asset for Europe', it seems to me that it wants to apply the whole of the EU to the outermost regions.
The recommendations on improving governance in cohesion are thus the first, somewhat anticipated, illustration of the implementation of territorial cohesion.

I hope that the overseas General States, which will soon be established in France, will do the same and will largely integrate the major territorial impact of European policies in favour of the RUB, whose added value is undeniable.
It is unquestionable.
We enjoy reading the conclusions of the Presidency of the last Council.
It resembles the victory announcement of all the defeated armies.
They have the devil in them, even in the repeated assertion that, once the crisis is over, the EU will build a stronger economy for the future or in the reaffirmation of a failing Lisbon strategy.
So, as they lock themselves in their glass towers, Eurocrats, Euro-philes and Europiomans of all kinds end up not taking things into their own hands.
Everyone knows that the euro area was the first to enter recession after experiencing the lowest interest rate in the world for eight years.
But it is also the one which is experiencing the greatest difficulties in terms of its industrial competitiveness and the employment situation.
Above all, it is the one which, by the general disarmament of the natural defences taken from the nations, is the least armed to react.
In reality, the only merit of this crisis will be to awaken the peoples, cradled in the facilities of financial anticipation and anti-national propaganda.
Only the Member States will have the legitimate instruments necessary for any major action, and to do so they will have to shake the reins of the EU and the euro.

For the French, in any case, it is becoming increasingly clear that there will be no salvation without France, no France without French policy, no French policy without national and popular sovereignty.

Madam President, I believe that the question of the distribution of foodstuffs to the most deprived is indeed quite timely, but I believe that, in essence, the Commission's proposal does not correspond to the problem.

The question of co-financing is a question that I ask myself, and I think it is rather the question of liberalism that has presided over the evaluations of the CAP in recent years that is being called into question.
The riots against hunger, the brutal variations in the price of foodstuffs are permanent indicators of the limits of the liberalisation of agricultural markets.
This liberalisation has always been at the expense of fragile populations, fragile producers and fragile territories.

I therefore call for politics to regain its rights, to regain its hand, both at European and at world level, and for the strategic field of agriculture and human nutrition, both in quantitative and qualitative terms, not to be subject to the strict laws of the market.
Of course, there is an urgency, and the Sikorsky report responds to that urgency, and I welcome that, but I hope that, in the case of the reflection that is opening up,
In the future of the CAP, it should be recalled that the priority objective is to combat, in a structural way, the hunger and poverty we know in all the Member States and in the world.
Rural areas are available to meet food needs through sufficient and quality production, but will they still have to be given the financial and human means to ensure this heavy responsibility?
Mr President, in this period of economic recession it was important that the European Union continue to show its solidarity with the developing countries.
In 2007, the European Community and the Member States together contributed 60 per cent of total development aid, making the European Union the world's largest donor.
The European Development Funds make it possible to combat poverty while promoting economic development and democracy.
I am therefore pleased that a budget of EUR 23 billion has been allocated to the ACP countries for the period 2008 under the 10th EDF, which is practically twice the amount foreseen for the 9th EDF.
The Court of Auditors concludes in its report that the accounts of the seventh, eighth and ninth EDFs are generally faithful, legal and regular.
We can only congratulate ourselves on the record levels of contract execution and payments for the implementation of the FEDs.
However, I also note that progress must be made in strengthening the control and surveillance system, as there is still a significant level of errors affecting certain transactions.
Similarly, there is too often a high risk of budgetary support and it is, in my view, appropriate to assess these risks better.
In this respect, I share the view that budgetary support should only be granted if the beneficiary country has the capacity to manage the funds in a transparent, responsible and efficient manner.

Mr President, among the priorities on which we must work in the future, I would like to mention the integration of the fact into the general budget, and I will conclude with the Community budget, because this would strengthen the efficiency and transparency of development aid.

In conclusion, Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, the representatives of the Court, but also all the staff of the Commission, who have done an excellent job on the spot, and I obviously regret the absence of the Council and, in particular, the Czech Presidency.
Madam President, Parliament and its rapporteur were forced to refuse a bad compromise, and they were right to do so.
Our delegation remained faithful to the position adopted very broadly in the plenary and which called for the abolition in time of any derogation from the legal duration of work.
But the truth is that Parliament was the only one who wanted to move things forward.
The representatives of the European people had decided, far beyond the partisan divisions, to put an end to this archaism called opt-out.
We were the only ones to propose a genuine compromise text which the Council of Ministers, like the Commission, has perfectly ignored.
The Council and the Commission have agreed on the position of those who strongly oppose any progress in workers' rights in Europe.
Mr President-in-Office of the Council, it is clear that you have reached your goal.
The Court of Justice obliges you to consider all guard time as working time, so you have lost nothing on that side.
The opt-out you want still exists in practice, so the real estate agent took it away.
More than ever, the Members elected next June will have to fight to achieve a high level of harmonisation of social standards.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you very much.

Mr President, it is certainly not in the name of the LIBE Committee and it is probably in the name of my group that I would like to take this brief moment to give my extremely positive assessment of Mrs Paganova's report.
Congratulations, Madam, on your report.

I believe that in writing this report you have drawn up an extraordinarily precise agenda of elements which should be included in the Stockholm programme, Commissioner, which I know the Commission is actively preparing.

Allow me to add to all that has been said about the importance of training magistrates, the importance of evaluation, to emphasize two fundamental elements of mutual trust which are at the basis of what could be mutual recognition tomorrow.
One, the independence of the judiciary.
There are currently a number of countries in the Union where the independence of the judiciary from political power or from other powers is not established.
It's a scandal, and it has to stop.
Secondly, procedural safeguards.

As long as we are not sure that in a number of countries people who are suspected or accused of committing certain types of crime benefit from procedural guarantees similar to those in other countries, it is difficult to make the principle of mutual recognition widely accepted.
It is a fundamental element and I wanted to introduce it into this debate.
Congratulations to you, Mrs. Pagat.
Madam President, we cannot remain silent on the situation in Madagascar and we will not be the only ones to condemn it.
The African Union, the Southern African Development Community, the International Organisation for Francophonie, the Interparliamentary Union, the European Union, to use the words of the Commission.

In the United States, a large number of countries, including my own and Norway, to speak of countries on the European continent, have condemned the coup d'√©tat, because it must be called a cat to a cat, which took place in Madagascar.
We cannot remain silent and ask for a return to constitutional legality.
We never ask for a return to the starting class, with, if necessary, arbitration by the Malagasy people through consultation in the form of a presidential election or referendum.
It is for the assemblies and political leaders of Madagascar to determine the most effective form of consultation.
So what we are asking for with this joint resolution is to add our voice to that of the international community to clearly signify those who have taken power in a completely different way.

It is democratic and, in the form of a coup d'√©tat, to return to the constitutional legality of Madagascar, which is one of the guarantors of the future development of this great island in the Indian Ocean.

Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, of course I would like to thank Commissioner Dimas for his presence and for his answers, for the attention he continues to pay to all these disasters.
We worked a lot together when President Barroso asked me to prepare a report, which he also cited, on the creation of a European civil protection force.
This report, which I presented on 9 May 2006,
When I read it again and see all the disasters that have occurred, I think it is still relevant.
Mrs Zavela, of course there is only Greece.
All the countries are affected, and then I would add that there are not only natural disasters, but also human disasters, due to man.
I am thinking of the maritime disasters, the Rika and many others, the industrial accidents of the Chernobyl type.
There are other natural disasters besides fires.
I think about the tsunami.
We may fear a tsunami in the Mediterranean one day, as there was one at the beginning of the 20th century that completely destroyed the city of Messina.
Frankly, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the tools we are mobilizing are not up to the standards of these disasters, which will multiply under the double effect of global warming and transport.
That's why I think we need to be more ambitious.
I thank the Commission, Commissioner Dimas and all his teams, the Directorate-General, who make the civil protection mechanism work.
I think we need to go further.
With the Member States that wish to do so, we can imagine enhanced cooperation.
If we're not twenty-seven to make this civil protection force, let's start being twelve or fifteen.
And then you'll see that it's going to affect everyone.
When I make the list of disasters, I can say that everyone is concerned about the floods that hit Germany in 2002, even the great pandemics and also terrorism.
That, Commissioner, is why I would like the Commission to take the initiative to go further, to propose to the Member States to go further.
Our Parliament, the Committee on the Environment, the Committee on Defence and Security will support you in your voluntary initiatives.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this summer again the Mediterranean forest was the prey of flames in Marseille, in southern Corsica, but also in Italy, in Spain and, on a larger scale, in Greece.
More than 400 hectares of forests and fields have been destroyed, causing considerable material losses, irreparable damage to biodiversity and dramatic loss of human life.
I am appalled by this record, which has been repeated year after year, and I am aware of the multiplier effect of global warming on fires.
I call for European awareness-raising for better coordination of efforts and the sharing of firefighting measures.
I would like to see the implementation of a large-scale project of Euro-Mediterranean cooperation to combat forest fires within the framework of the Union for the Mediterranean.
I welcome the existing initiatives, in particular the European Forest Fire Information System, a pilot project.
Nevertheless, I call for a reform of the European Union Solidarity Fund so that it becomes a powerful tool for responding to crises and a reinforcement of the European Union's strength.
protection and the Euro-Aid scheme devised by Michel Barnier in 2006 to intervene on the territory of the 27 Member States as well as abroad.

I think that one of the keys to the problem of forest fires lies in the exchange of knowledge and good practice in the field of prevention, and I would like to point out the pioneering role played by sapper foresters in my own department.
I can, of course, make this example available to Europe, which can serve as an example.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, I will be brief.
I think there are two elements in this debate.
The question is how to get out of this crisis.
All the measures that go, both to help farmers and to intervene, are necessary and absolutely necessary.
We must support them and even consider that they are more important.
That is what we are proposing with a number of colleagues here in Parliament.
Secondly, there is a question of structural management of the milk market, and that is where there is a divergence with you, Commissioner.
You are proposing to go in the direction of contracting.

I tell you in advance that the contractual relationship between industrialists and farmers in the long term, since industries are competitive with each other, will lead to competition on a European scale.
We need public regulation to regulate a market.
There is no other alternative.
That is where the debate will have to start after this crisis.
I think that in this debate we must respect all opinions and all options, and I am afraid that we have gone too fast at the time of the health balance to settle an issue such as quotas.

So far, I say to all those who have intervened, we have made it possible both to maintain dairy production in Europe, to ensure an extremely developed dairy industry and, at the same time, to ensure a price for consumers which has been quite bearable so far.
Mr President, a few days after the positive referendum in Ireland, I really have the impression that we can say that we are more European today than before.
I'm really, really, really happy about that.
Unfortunately, unfortunately, we are still essentially dependent on the decision of the Constitutional Court, but also on the goodwill of the Czech President.

We must send a clear signal of responsibility to those who hold the future of this treaty in their hands, which is crucial for the Union, for our institutions and for the 500 million Europeans we represent.
We can no longer be hostages to a few whose sole purpose is to counteract the general European interest.
If it is legitimate for some to wish not to go further in European integration, if it is legitimate to share these reluctances, it is also legitimate to let those who wish to do so progress.
In general, the processes of ratification of European treaties too often take the form of a saga or a victory at the last minute.
Are we condemned to constantly have to force to ensure the implementation of a treaty and its institutional reforms?
We will have to learn the lessons of this chaotic ratification process and also, of course, of this commitment to negotiate the organisation of a second one.
A referendum in Ireland, as if it were normal to re-vote a people who have expressed themselves in a sovereign way, and as if it were normal for an assent to a treaty to be a bargaining chip.
It is a question of the coherence and institutional balance of the European adventure.
Ratifying a treaty is a minimum requirement of loyalty and cohesion from the moment one chooses for one's country to join the European Union.
We wanted to send a strong signal to the citizens by ratifying the Treaty for the European elections in June 2009.
What do you think the citizen thinks today of the Treaty of Lisbon, and beyond our internal coherence and our legitimacy?
Mr President, my speech is about the deterioration of working conditions in Europe.
Today, nearly half the world's workers earn less than two dollars a day.
12.3 million people are still enslaved and more than 200 million children are forced to work.
In Europe, the number of poor workers is increasing day by day, and the International Labour Organization counts 160 deaths each year due to lack of prevention.
In this context, I would like to emphasize our responsibility towards all those who are unemployed and have social rights and who work in unworthy conditions.
Of these millions of workers who suffer morally and physically, sometimes driven to suicide or victims of cancer or chronic illness due to their working conditions.
It's time to get out of the religion of working more, of the race for profit, of short-term competition.
Decent work rights and the strengthening of the right to work must be at the forefront of the Union's priorities in the next ten years.
Madam President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Mr President-in-Office of the Commission, a challenge, a challenge for humanity, a challenge for future generations.
In order to lift the lid, Copenhagen must allow for a comprehensive agreement, a single agreement, as our chairman of the Environment Committee, J√≥zsef Lajƒç√°n N√°nou, has just pointed out.

Today, with our debate but also with the drafting of a resolution by our Parliament, we call again on the European Union to retain its leading role in this necessary policy of combating climate change.
Let us remember that we should speak with one voice to maintain our credibility.
Yes, we must reach an agreement in Copenhagen to limit the increase in the global average temperature to a level not exceeding two degrees above pre-industrial levels.
Yes, we must sign an agreement in Copenhagen to achieve collective reductions in greenhouse gas emissions of 30 by 2020 compared to 1990.
But that won't be enough.
It is not only necessary for developed countries to reduce their emissions considerably, but also for developing countries to contribute to the achievement of the objectives.

Industrialized countries must therefore provide sufficient, sustainable and predictable financial and technical support to developing countries to encourage them to commit to reducing their greenhouse gas emissions.
Copenhagen must thus enable developing countries to move towards carbon-neutral models.
You too, allow me to address two points which seem necessary to me for our future.
Firstly, the global implementation of climate finance based on the taxation of financial transactions.
Secondly, it seems to me necessary to put in place a tax adjustment at Europe's borders which would affect the import of manufactured goods without any concern for the protection of the environment.

There is a contracting and refunding to the southern countries of the carbon tax thus collected at the borders of Europe and which would be used to finance investments in the equipment needed to combat global warming.
Mr President, I would like to speak in the same vein as my speech yesterday on the preparations for the Copenhagen summit, and following yesterday's Ecofin meeting, which was not a success.
I asked you about the responsibility we have as industrialized countries to ensure that developing countries can follow us in our efforts to combat climate change.
In Copenhagen we cannot pretend that we all have the same capacities, otherwise it would mean that we all start from the same point and end up with nothing.
So, in order to convince our developing partners to join us, we will obviously have to address the question of the aid to be granted to them and not wait for the outcome of the Copenhagen summit.
At the next European Council, the 27 will have to agree on how the European Union intends to help developing countries in the important context of climate change.
Yesterday, as I said, the Ecofin Council and the Finance Ministers were unable to reach a common position on this issue.
Yet we know that this question is absolutely central.

The European Commission had already made proposals, and I very much hope that we will take the lead in leading our partners towards the global solidarity needed to overcome this problem of climate change.

Mr President, I would like to thank the Swedish Presidency for its efforts to reach an ambitious agreement in Copenhagen, despite the very strong wind of pessimism blowing over these future negotiations.
For my part, I think it is not realistic to admit at this stage that the Copenhagen Summit is dead or that it will not lead to a final agreement to be ratified by all parties.
Let's not give in to pessimism too quickly.
I urge that at this stage we do not look back at our declining ambitions, either in terms of objectives or deadlines.
We must continue to believe in a comprehensive, ambitious and binding global political agreement, paving the way for the conclusion of a legal treaty as soon as possible.
It is really too early to talk about the deadline for COP 16 in December 2010.
We must now translate our rhetoric into real political will.
We need to clarify our commitment in terms of financial and aid to developing countries, particularly in terms of technological transfers.
At this stage, a total and collective commitment by the European Union is essential.
I also note on paper the recent but exemplary momentum given, for example, by Brazil, South Korea, Indonesia and Norway, which have set their ambitions to reduce their pollutant emissions.

If we can understand the flexibility demanded by the United States, which is only beginning to take the climate issue into account, we will still have to reach quantified, binding and ambitious short, medium and long-term commitments from other major polluters, such as the United States and China.
Otherwise, we are facing climate, political and moral disasters.
Madam President, we all know and we all have said the importance of the Copenhagen negotiations, but if we all hope for an agreement, we cannot accept an agreement at any price.
If the conditions for an ambitious agreement are not met, I very clearly wish that the European Union would be able to say no and refuse to sign a discounted agreement.
The European populations we represent here are waiting for an agreement, an agreement that will make it possible to combat effectively all the climate disruptions that we see around us every day.

They will not be satisfied with facts of announcement, statements of unstated intentions, unconstraining objectives on which it will be possible to wipe one's feet once the media projector is turned off.

In Copenhagen, the Member States will have to commit themselves, and the European Union, the only continent to have seen its CO2 emissions decrease since 1990, the only continent to have made precise, binding and ambitious commitments for the future, cannot bear the burden of the effort alone.

That is why, if other industrialised and emerging countries do not want to take their share of the burden, we must draw all the consequences by introducing a tax at our borders to protect our industry from competition from those who would decide not to participate in a global agreement.
We Europeans are asking our industrialists a little more every day.
I want to use the climate package, which was signed under the French Presidency, as proof.
I want to prove this by national initiatives which, like the carbon tax, which was recently welcomed by Mr Pargno and which I welcome, are promoting the introduction of an ecological tax.

A sector such as transport, which is one of the largest emitters of CO2, even though some modes of transport, such as aviation, emit less greenhouse gases, is increasingly contributing to the fight against climate change.
However, this is an area which has suffered very badly from the crisis.

If, as I hope, maritime and air transport are integrated into the negotiations in Copenhagen, then let us ensure that what is asked of European industries is also asked of those of other industrialised countries.
In Copenhagen, the world public will have its eyes fixed on its ruling class.
Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Copenhagen Summit is a historic opportunity to change the course of the planet.
We must reach decisions that are even more binding than those taken in Kyoto.
We too must call on our leaders to create an international organization, such as the World Trade Organization, to regulate climate change and the environment, to create a
adaptation to climate change, in addition, of course, to public development aid, to create a carbon, maritime and air tax, as we must also do on financial transactions.
We see the urgent need for global environmental regulation, such as financial markets and the Internet.
We have the opportunity to open this path of history through the environment.
Let us do so in the image of our highest human aspirations, otherwise we will appear as responsible, with no grip on the reality of things.

Madam President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Mr President-in-Office of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, less than two weeks after the Copenhagen conference, concerns are growing about the success of the negotiations on climate change.
Some people already say it's going to be a failure.
The great world powers are still reluctant to show all the ambition that the climate emergency imposes on us.

By adopting the motion for a resolution on the European Union's strategy before the Copenhagen conference tomorrow, we Members of the European Parliament must show that our determination is first and foremost total and that the conference must lead to an agreement which is precise but, above all, binding.
Moreover, the binding nature of this agreement, which will be found, must not be called into question or called into question.

We cannot postpone the decision-making indefinitely until tomorrow, otherwise it will be too late, hence the need to create a World Environment Organization, which today seems not only necessary but also urgent, since it will be brought under the auspices of the UN to control the implementation of the commitments made in Copenhagen.
We must be able to expect from Copenhagen, from the great confidence of this world, more clarity and responsibility.
Mr President, I would like to support the joint initiative of the British Socialist Government and the French Government to return illegal Afghans to their territories.
Indeed, contrary to what some people have said, these people had seen their request for political asylum rejected and this bilateral initiative must now be extended at European level.

Mr President, the migration pressure is a challenge which we must tackle collectively, and this is the meaning of the Pact on Immigration and Asylum, which was voted on a few months ago and adopted a few months ago under the French Presidency.
We must now go further by pooling our resources and organising joint return flights financed by Frontex.

The decision of the Twenty-Seven to ask the Commission for a study on this subject is a first step and, Commissioner, I would like the Commission to support this proposal because the fight against illegal immigration is an expectation of public opinion and, in particular, of the regularly migrating populations.
Mr President, I would like to return to a recent event, the Swiss vote on the minerals.
It is true that this vote took place in a non-member state of the European Union, but it is clear that it concerns a question which is not foreign to us.
I would like to return to this event because I also see it as a pretext to talk about secularism, and there is never too much talk about secularism in this Chamber.
It is necessary and urgent that the principle of secularism dominate the organization of our society, and I would like to say simple things here.
First of all, the opposite principle of secularism is not religiosity, much less spirituality.
The principle contrary to secularism is religious communitarianism, which dictates rules and laws superior to civil laws, communitarianism which locks individuals in infrasocial groups.
Our Union, through its history, is multicultural and multiethnic.
It is, and will be, more and more, and only secularism can allow individuals
Mr President, the CESAR programme, which aims to modernise air traffic management in Europe, is a major project.

How will the Commission prepare the next phase of the redeployment of C√¶sar and, in particular, the financing of this programme, which is essential for the environment and for our scientific and technical outreach?
Will the Commission follow the recommendations of the report submitted in 2007 that a high-level qualified person should ensure the political follow-up of this programme?
Indeed, it will require overcoming many legal, psychological and technical obstacles by unifying national airspace and by having the controllers of the different countries work together.
If Europe was not able to unify its sky, how could it be able to build a strong political entity?
Mr President, Madam Minister, ladies and gentlemen, the importance of the issue of climate change is no longer being proven.
These short, medium and long-term impacts are undeniable, even if today the results of the GSE in a certain national newspaper are certainly strengthening the positions of the skeptics.
The Copenhagen Summit has appeared in the eyes of the world as a unique opportunity for world leaders to witness, act and correct the effects of this process that is climate change.

The European Union was at the forefront of this forum, not only because of the bold legislation we have in place to limit the impact of our activities on the climate, but also because Europe is a union of countries that can really make a difference.
Of course, the outcome of the Copenhagen conference can only leave a taste of dissatisfaction, but I refuse to talk about failure.
The world has agreed on the question of limiting the increase in temperature to two degrees, even for a country as reluctant as China.
Brazil has just passed a law aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions by almost 39 by 2020, in line with its commitments.
Many others have also shown great ambition for greenhouse gas emission reduction targets.
I think of Japan and Norway.
In addition, it is also necessary to emphasize this very positive point that the consensus reached on the urgency of a mechanism for reducing emissions due to deforestation.
A specific and unanimous text was obtained on the implementation of the IRED mechanism to reduce deforestation and thus allow the natural storage of CO2.
Far from being a binding agreement, but clearly in the line of a political agreement, the outcome of Copenhagen must lead us to question the reasons for such a disappointment.
I went to the Copenhagen Conference, like many of my colleagues, with the desire to participate, to help, to see a negotiating Europe, a leading Europe, act.
My disappointment was great because Europe clearly did not have the place it deserved in the negotiations, especially when it comes to the European Parliament.
To prevail, Europe must show itself to be stronger on this issue.
The meeting of our ministers on the environment in Seville did not take place, and our officials were uncertain, hesitant, and we remain divided on our objectives.
I hope that Mrs Hedegaard, with her proposals and commitments to the Committee on the Environment, will be able to bring the ambitions of the European Union back to a new level.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in order to escape the caricatures we have heard a few of this morning, I would like to recall a few objective elements concerning Tunisia, a partner country of the European Union.

The social situation has evolved very favourably, with a spectacular progression in the average income per capita and, from now on, the vast majority of Tunisians fall within the criteria defining belonging to the middle class.

More than 90 per cent of Tunisians benefit from social coverage and more than a quarter of Tunisia's budget is devoted to education, making it one of the first countries to achieve the Millennium Development Goals for primary education.
Finally, as Mr Michel has just pointed out, women's rights are recognised and guaranteed.
At the university, there are more female students than male students, 40 percent of the teachers are women, a quarter of the deputies or local elected officials or journalists are women.
Many countries could envy such results.
Mr President, the acts of fanatical criminals who have killed Christians in Egypt cannot be blamed on an entire people and their government.
It would be unfair to hold Egypt and the Egyptians responsible for this abominable massacre, the perpetrators of which will be judged.
Let us not confuse the actions of a criminal with the politics of a country, let us not amalgamate fanatics with a whole population.
Between the Coptic Christians of Egypt and their Muslim compatriots, we give arguments to the extremists who seek to present the Christians of the East as agents of the West.
I understand, excuse me, Madam President, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, that what is happening in Greece, Portugal, Spain or Ireland tomorrow is scandalous.

These same Anglo-Saxon agencies, which complacently noted the emitters and traders of toxic assets and saw nothing come, are today of the last severity towards the states that flew to the aid of a financial sector that did not deserve it.

The crisis caused by the irresponsibility of the markets and the banks and this massive aid are directly at the origin of the worsening of the deficits and the public debt that these same markets now claim to sanction.
This is the moralization of capitalism proclaimed by Mr Sarkozy, the European Union and the G20.

All the banksters have learned from the crisis is that the taxpayer is an inexhaustible source of profit and insurance resources, because the rumor that the scale of this panic comes from a large American bank that has benefited from the help of the government.

American and two hedge funds of the same nationality who want to win both on the exorbitant interest rates imposed on Greece and on the CDS market, these insurance on state loans, which are themselves the subject of independent speculation.
It will not be enough to regulate the hedge funds, which you are afraid to do, or the derivatives markets, as Mr Barnier proposes.
It is useless to create a European economic government.
The 27 are in the same boat anyway and solidarity is not an option.
It is the free movement of capital around the world that must be called into question, otherwise there will be no
Mr President, there are now less than 15 of the red-collar workers left.
In the face of such figures, the solution seems obvious.
However, we must not forget the jobs involved in the decisions we are taking today.
It should be recalled that CITES is not intended to prohibit fishing, but only the international trade of this fish, 80 of which is exported to Japan.

Mr President, while safeguarding tuna, we are protecting a dangerously prized species, but we are also encouraging the maintenance of a more balanced, more sustainable fishing activity, a fishery for our internal market and a source of employment.

Mr President, I am in favour of the idea of including red tuna in Annex I of CITES, and although it seems to me that this decision will be positive, the Commission's help in allowing a thorough restructuring of the fisheries sector is welcome.
My question therefore concerns the modalities of this support.
France is calling for a delay of 18 months, accompanied by financial measures for sailors and shipowners concerned by a ban on trade.
What is the Commission's view on this matter?
Moreover, my concern, like that of many of my colleagues, is about fairness.
How can we ensure that ships flying the flag of countries such as Tunisia, Libya or others will apply the ban on international trade with a rigor comparable to ours?
What will be the new control and sanction measures?

The sustainability policy of our economic activities must be concrete, sometimes even unpopular in some sectors, but I hope that the Commission and the Council will not lose sight of the adjustments necessary for the implementation of these measures.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, as the rapporteur has said, this proposal for a directive is indeed the result of a vote in Parliament, as you have also recalled, Commissioner.
However, my group remains extremely critical of this proposal because it risks turning against those we want to support.
In order to lighten the burden on businesses, we risk depriving them of the conditions of transparency and trust necessary for their management and the dynamism of their activities.
First of all, I think we need to be clear about thresholds and what we call micro-entities.
These are SMEs with more than 10 employees, with a turnover of more than EUR 1 million.
Whatever the Member State, it represents a very large majority of enterprises.
It is true that they may be local and uncommon in the Community market, but it remains that the need to present accounting rules will not be abolished for them and that
They will have to face them every time they want to deal with a banking body, with partners or sometimes negotiate with the fiscal, economic and social institutions.

At that time, accounting rules will be imposed on them and they will have to pay, perhaps more expensive than for regular accounting, in order to be able to meet criteria that they will not necessarily master.
I do not see any progress in the fact that the accounting obligation is imposed outside any common framework for the European Union.
This is not simply a problem of competition, it is simply a question of economic integration and Community law and equal treatment for all businesses in the European Union.
That being said, of course, simplification of accounting obligations for SMEs is a necessity.
Three initiatives are going in this direction, whether it is the proposal we are talking about today or the international reference IFO.
I would like to see the fourth and seventh accounting directives revised, for which the European Commission should soon make proposals to us.
These proposals were promised to us for 2010 and it would seem that they have been extended, but I do not think that this extension of the deadline is a sufficient reason for this.
