I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission's proposal for a directive on the protection of workers from the risks related to exposure to carcinogens and mutagens has been rejected by the Council.

It is clearer for businesses to provide them with a single and comprehensive response, which will enable them to reconcile the objective of simplifying the obligations desired by all and the reality of life for small businesses in need.
The current problem is that the European Commission is dragging its feet in proposing a revision of these directives and that this is detrimental to our thinking.

I therefore call on the European Commission to speed up the dialogue on the issue of exemption, which today divides both the European institutions and the economic environment, and to carry out an impact assessment.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, as my colleague Elisabeth Morin Chartier and the other colleagues have pointed out, on 27 and 28 February last the violent storm Xanthia struck several French regions, causing 53 casualties and enormous material damage.
The storm was of rare intensity, causing devastating floods on the French coast.
After Madeira, Europe is once again affected.
Britain, the region of my colleague and friend Alain Cadec, has been badly affected.
Three French departments have thus been declared in a state of natural disaster: Brittany, Poitou-Charentes and the Loire countries.
In the face of these disasters, the European Union must show its reactivity and express its solidarity.
It is not only through words and a resolution, but also and above all through financial aid that we will be able to support the victims of these disasters.

I therefore invite, and my colleague Christophe Becciu is joining me in this, the European Commission to quickly unblock the Union Solidarity Fund to help the affected regions to cope with the damage.
This disaster demonstrates the relevance of Michel Barnier's proposal to create a European Civil Intervention Force.

Europeans must act together because disasters are multiplying and affecting our European territories, and in particular our most isolated and vulnerable regions, such as the islands in the Indian Ocean and the Caribbean.

Madam President, I too would like to congratulate our rapporteur, J√ºrg Leichtfried, on his text and his spirit of cooperation on this matter, and I support in particular his proposals on the financing of air safety, since we are talking here about air safety and not air safety.

For many years our Commission has been fighting to accept the principle that the strictest security measures must be the responsibility of the Member States, and I fully support our rapporteur on this point.
Indeed, safety is not only a matter for travellers, but for all citizens, and it is the responsibility of States to take measures to combat terrorism.
It is therefore not justified for air passengers to be the only ones responsible for financing safety measures at airports and on board aircraft.
This is all the more so since, in modes of transport such as rail and maritime, States finance, as the case may be, partially or totally safety measures.
I therefore believe that we must stand firm in the face of the Council and defend to the end Amendment No 32 to the report adopted by our Committee on Transport.
I had another point to address quickly.

While I support the progress made in the area of non-discrimination and transparency, I do not believe that the aim of this directive is to establish a single and identical European system of security charges.
While compelling compliance with the common rules, Member States must be allowed to maintain their current system of levying fees.

Thus, in countries such as Spain, Italy and France, the levies are voted on by Parliament and, in this case, it must be the authority to appeal against the laws which must act as an independent supervisory authority.
And that is the subject of Amendment No 40, which I hope many of you will support when we vote on it.
Mr President, Commissioner, the report I am presenting to Parliament is an attempt to explain that agriculture has a place and a role to play in the fight against global warming.
Nature reminds us this week that volcanoes in particular can have a major impact on human activities and on the climate.
But it does require, nevertheless, that men and Europe in particular take responsibility for fighting what is called climate change.
My report tries to show that agriculture can both continue to reduce its carbon emissions, to reduce its fossil energy consumption and then, above all, to reduce its carbon emissions.
On the other hand, it has been very active in fixing carbon to fight, overall, for less carbon emissions and more carbon captured and sequestered.
This report tries to show that in agriculture we should go from a compartmentalised approach, which consists of opening a directive whenever we have a problem.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has already made a number of proposals in this area, and if he is aware of the fact that the Commission has already made a number of proposals in this area.

In this approach, we must be able to find ways of ensuring that agriculture, as I said earlier, not only reduces its energy consumption, but at the same time participates very actively in the fixation of carbon.
In particular, it is the role of photosynthesis, of biomass, and above all, what I care about, which is also linked to the soil, to the capacity that European soils have to fix organic carbon.

I think that this track, which I am opening in this report and which I hope will be followed at the vote in plenary in Brussels, must enable European agriculture to enter a phase of sustainability, of ensuring

An ecological transition to this agriculture, which would put it ahead of a number of other continents or other agriculture to ensure that it is able to be economically, ecologically and I also think, from that moment on, socially performing.

This report deals with a particular issue, the fight against global warming and agriculture, but it claims, I hope, to open up other perspectives to feed, in particular, the debate on the future of agricultural policy after 2013.
I am addressing the Commission, which I have often done in the Committee on Agriculture, and I will also address the various ministers when I have the opportunity.
I think we need to take a turn.
This 2013 package must be ambitious.
It must be based on objectives which enable citizens to understand why we need a common agricultural policy.
We need a common agricultural policy, because the Europe of agriculture must ensure both food security and commit itself to sustainability.
That is what I am proposing in this report and that is what I hope Parliament will follow with a large majority.

Mr President, I would first of all like to emphasize that the precautionary principle applied by most European governments in closing their airspace in a targeted and temporary manner was a wise and prudent decision.

The safety of our fellow citizens must take precedence over all other considerations, and in these conditions the attitude of some airlines, which call for the total and immediate reopening of the airspace on both one or two test flights, seems at least indecent.

I believe that it was Mr Henain who spoke earlier about the complementarity of modes of transport, particularly with the train, and I will take this opportunity to say how much I regret that air paralysis
In some countries, such as France, the disorganization of rail transport has been accentuated by strikes in irresponsible and incomprehensible circumstances.
To return to our subject, I would like to welcome the Commission's decision to authorise the granting of public aid to airlines affected by the ongoing disturbances.
And it is a sensible decision in a context already marked by the crisis, but this aid must be exceptional.

In this respect, I would like the exemplary nature of the compensation granted to their customers who have been the victims of flight cancellations to be included among the criteria adopted for their grant.
It is unacceptable that some companies abuse the major force clause in order to evade their obligation to compensate passengers under Regulation No 261.
Travellers are victims of the current situation and if no alternative solution is offered to them, they must not, moreover, bear the financial cost.
In addition, travel agencies are exempt from the obligation to reimburse passengers for unused flights.
And that's not normal either.

Companies, like travel agencies, have insurance that covers them in exceptional cases, like the one we've been living in for the past few days, and so we have to make sure that travelers are well compensated for the flights that have been cancelled.
Mr President, there is no shortage of words in the press to refer to the closure of European airspace and its consequences.
I will not dwell on what has already been said, particularly when we are crying out about the colossal, abysmal financial impact, one would try to say, of this crisis, in direct or indirect terms.

Although I welcome the possibility of considering the granting of exceptional public aid to the air transport sector, which has already been strongly approved since 11 September 2001, I am nevertheless puzzled by the European management of events.

1. knowing that 750 European passengers have been injured, many of whom are still stuck in the four corners of the world, knowing that economic losses are exponential over time, how to explain the fact that it has taken
It is not one, two, three or four, but five days for the European transport ministers to meet by teleconference to coordinate their actions and decide on the creation of differentiated traffic zones.
Secondly, no one disputes the need to apply the precautionary principle as a top priority, but today, as traffic in certain areas is gradually being re-authorised,
With unchanged weather and while the volcano is still active, we have the right to wonder what additional safety guarantees for passengers we could have provided sooner, sooner.

Thirdly, an evolutionary action model has been developed, the evolution according to the weather and the activity of the volcano can change from hour to hour, which will continue to proceed with the updated assessment of corridor safety.
Should these test flights be carried out by civil aviation and airlines?

Finally, if this continues, worsens or reproduces what is likely, the management model put in place will have to provide for greater coordination between Member States and special operational procedures based on real data.

Coordination of other means of transport in exceptional circumstances, but also taking into account the necessary coordination of aid for the repatriation of the tens of thousands of stranded passengers who also have the right to information and assistance.
So far, only isolated and national initiatives have been taken.

Madam President, I would like, in turn, after other speakers, to express my thanks to our colleague M√©ndez de Vigo, who has done a remarkable job, sometimes in passionate and always passionate conditions.

The debates in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs have lasted a long time, they have been up to the challenge and up to the intensity of the interest that the Members of the Commission are obviously putting into it.

The European Parliament, in the main subject which concerns them, the first leaders, in a quite legitimate way, the composition of our Assembly and the modalities of appointment of the members of our Assembly.
Once again, the rapporteur has been able to gather opinions and sometimes different contributions and to synthesise, I would say, in an extremely balanced text, opinions and opinions.
I wanted to thank him for that.

I believe that the recommendations of these two reports, both those concerning the convening of the CIG and those concerning the transitional measures for the composition of our Assembly, are marked by realism, pragmatism and efficiency.
I believe that this is what our fellow citizens expect from Europe on a global scale and on other issues as well.
Mr President, Mr Dalli, Mr Commissioner, it is with great force that this draft report, as presented by Mr Peterle, takes up the lines of the Commission's proposal.
This is a guideline in the European Commission's communication and is also inspired by the European Parliament's resolution of 10 April 2008 on the fight against cancer in our European Union.

Let me support the objectives of the European partnership envisaged by the European Commission to combat cancer more effectively, whether it is the importance of preventing early detection, the development of a new cancer prevention model and, above all, the reduction of inequalities within the Member States.
I share the concerns and concerns expressed in the European Commission's communication and the draft report.
I would like to congratulate Mr Peterle, the rapporteur, on the work he has done in drawing up this report and on the compromise proposals put forward to take up the various amendments.

As a fictitious rapporteur for the Socialist and Democratic Group, I wanted to focus on the following issues: first, the increase in annual deaths from cancer caused by exposure to carcinogenic agents at work, but also the importance of better access to care.

information on medicines for cancer patients, but also the implementation of the REACH Regulation and the regular update of very worrying substances, including carcinogens, and support for initiatives to prevent the import of goods.
It is also important to ensure that the European Union's chemical legislation is in line with the European Union's international obligations on the protection of human health and the environment.
These are the questions we have asked while supporting this draft report.
Madam President, the leakage of oil from the Gulf of Mexico is a real ecological and economic disaster.
It would appear that irregularities have been found in the granting of forest permits by the U.S. Department of the Interior.
This would be an unforgivable frivolity whose consequences are incalculable and do not concern only the United States of America.

When we know that in the world hundreds of offshore drilling permits are granted by states, if these permits are granted with the same lightness, it would pose a real serious problem to the whole world.
The European Union's external borders are divided into three parts: the external borders of the European Union and the external borders of the European Union.
In total, spread over the three continents, I must say here that I am very concerned about our islands in relation to offshore oil projects.
This is why it is imperative that the European Union, in order to set an example, review with the utmost rigour the safety and prevention measures on its own offshore oil platforms.
In addition, accidental or operational spillages of oil into the sea, not necessarily from Europe, are estimated at several tens of thousands of tons each year.

Should the European Union not take initiatives to ensure that maritime platforms are now part of an unchallenged international scientific authority which should be set up in the form of an international authority?
After Copenhagen and in preparation for Cancun, the European Union would be honoured to initiate genuine global governance for the research, protection and exploitation of marine resources.
With the continuation of the Barcelona process, the Union for the Mediterranean is an opportunity to develop our relations with the countries of the eastern and southern Mediterranean basin.
As the excellent report by Vincent Peillon points out, we cannot ignore the potential of this region or the dangers it poses.
However, with the lucidity to recognize that since the bombing of Gaza and with the continuation of the colonization of Palestinian territories, the Union for the Mediterranean is at an impasse.
The political aspect is blocked.
It is not even certain that the summit scheduled for next June in Barcelona will take place.
I would not be surprised if we learned in the coming hours or days that it has been postponed, Sinedier.
We must not give up, but the European Union must take more responsibility in finding a political solution.
We cannot leave the United States the monopoly of political crisis management in this region, which is ours, by merely contributing to its development.
The development and stability of the Mediterranean are the conditions for our security and our growth, and for this reason the Union for the Mediterranean remains the best instrument at our disposal.
Mr President, Commissioner, this is an extremely important issue concerning consumer protection.
A recent survey shows that the food security situation has deteriorated in the last ten years in the eyes of Europeans, and one in three consumers remains suspicious of the quality of products.
Updating, simplifying and clarifying the labelling of foodstuffs in the European Union is therefore an obligation for better consumer protection.
Let me address two points.
As far as the colour code is concerned, we are in favour of this colour code if it is accompanied by a reference to nutritional values expressed in percentages.
And then I am opposed to a mandatory nutritional declaration for wines and spirits.
We want a specific regulation on spirits and spirits to be drawn up in the next three years instead of the five years proposed by the European Commission.
That is what I wanted to say, Mr President, Commissioner.
Mr President, Madam High Representative, this attack on a civilian ship by Israeli commandos obviously requires an impartial and credible investigation.
But what credit could we give to a Commission which would be both a judge and a party?
This attack took place in international waters and therefore concerns the international community, in particular Europe, the Mediterranean coast.
Europe, which should make itself more heard and be more strongly involved in the search for a political solution based on two states, each with Jerusalem as its capital.

Europe is making considerable financial efforts to contribute to the development of the Palestinian territories, but unfortunately it is too absent from the political process that should lead to the creation of this Palestinian State.
The financial and budgetary goodwill we show is not enough.
We must also express a political will and take the means to make ourselves heard.
The brutal killing of Mavi Marmara by the Israeli army is causing emotion and condemnation.
I would like to express my condolences to the nine victims of the attack on civilians, because this reasoning in international waters constitutes a violation of international law.

In doing so, the Israeli government is punishing its people, because in the end, we see, with the strengthening of the extremes, the ultimate goal of security in the region moving a little further away.
Yes, more than ever, the Israeli government must abandon the policy of force.
I would, however, like to point out that the strong media coverage of the Mavi Marmara flotilla, orchestrated from Turkey, casts doubt on the exclusively humanitarian purpose of this operation.
An investigation seems essential to shed light on the assault, but also on the preparations that preceded this expedition.
And I hope that the Israeli government will accept that this investigation includes substantial international involvement in order to finally find the paths of justice in this region.
Madam President, Madam High Representative, I welcome the new dynamic brought about by the launch of the Partnership for Modernisation and its pragmatism.
This new partnership, if it were only for this purpose, would at least have the merit of underlining the extent to which Russia is an indispensable geopolitical partner for the European Union.
I also welcome the positive comments on cooperation with Russia in crisis management.
A few remarks, however.

While the Union's requirements are always put forward, its partner's interests or positions seem to be systematically underestimated or disregarded, whether in the field of energy or in the way it can analyse the Eastern Partnership and the Atlantic aspirations of its closest neighbours.
I also note that the firmness of most of the Member States and the Union in their speeches, the virulence of the condemnations of human rights violations, seems to be reserved for Russia alone.

There is more talk of the police and more filthy diplomacy, as in the case of China, for example, of these systematic violations of the rule of law, whether it be about the lawyers of this world factory, in view of the minimum European social requirements when our French or European workers are unemployed.

Let me remind you of the adage, Adangusta, father Augusta, to the summits by the narrow roads, because that is how I consider the efforts of today's Russia, freed from the Marxist criminal poison that for so many decades has bled and locked up this country.
The current Russian Confederation will have been able to lift the head of an entire nation, despite the difficulties and important challenges it still faces.

So a little modesty, ladies and gentlemen, especially when the European superstate itself does not achieve any of its good objectives, despite the increasingly expensive means and the progressive domination of the states of Western and Central and Eastern Europe.
I cannot help but recall that this Assembly had more indulgence for the more communist Soviet Union than for Russia.

They are often the same people who yesterday campaigned for the unilateral disarmament of the West and for participation in Mr Gorbachev's House of Commons, who today feel the most virtuous indignation and the greatest shame at the Union-Russia partnership.

In this connection, I must inform you, if you are not yet aware, of new historical facts which will emerge from the gradual translation of the secret Soviet archives which a brave Mr Pavel Stroilov has been able to obtain, archives which have already given and will still give much.

It is an unpleasant surprise to the leaders of the single thought as to the reality of the end of the Cold War, which was really Mr Gorbachev, and the failure of today's powerful Europeanists, who then enthusiastically wanted to make possible certain Soviet projects.
At the risk of repeating myself, Russia is an essential and strategic partner for the European states and our relations must be strengthened for the benefit of all parties.
This country is much closer to us in terms of culture, civilization, history, geography, mutual interest or common risk than are some of the States which you are preparing to join the European Union.
As the President of the Council, we often say that necessity makes law.
In the face of the crisis, an obvious need has become inevitable, that of innovation, of being creative.

In this respect, I welcome the step taken by the Council, a step which I hope will eventually be a giant step towards genuine economic governance, because let us not be mistaken, the simple coordination of economic policies will remain insufficient.
Can we achieve a genuine budgetary federation, not because of circumstances, but because we ourselves would have decided to do so?
Let us return to the Council's decisions, which still make me happy.
The strengthening of the preventive aspect of the Stability and Growth Pact is an excellent thing, but there is no real budgetary discipline without sanctions for those who violate it.
They have been strengthened, but not yet specified, which is a pity.

Otherwise, I will tell you my satisfaction, among other things, with the guidelines decided, such as the famous competitiveness evaluation scoreboard, because that is what it is all about, renewed with competitiveness and sustainable growth for all.
I would also like to congratulate the Commission on its proposal to introduce a banking tax, to accept a tax on financial transactions and to accelerate the reform of financial regulation.
Mr President-in-Office of the Council, all these decisions and guidelines seemed, a few months or even weeks ago, unrealistic, illusory or even really hypothetical.
You are right, it is true, it is a profound cultural change on the scale of the policy of the European small steps.
However, it is now mandatory for the States to implement these guidelines very concretely in October.

It will now be up to the Council to decide whether the step taken is a historic giant step or simply a pious vow, which we will all bitterly regret, and in particular a majority of citizens will suffer on a daily basis.

Mr President, we have already discussed this at the Conference of Presidents, and many groups are divided on this Gallo report, and it is clear that Parliament, all the groups, still need to discuss it because there are contradictory points which the groups have not been able to resolve.
That is why we asked for the debate and the vote on the Galois report to be postponed, i.e. to be held on 2 September, which will have to be seen at the Conference of Presidents.
So it's a very simple thing.
Since the fruit is not ripe, let's leave it to ripen in the summer and discuss it in September.

Madam President, I confess that I have difficulty in following my colleagues who like to show their muscles and take advantage of the monopoly of our legitimacy vis-√†-vis the other institutions of the Union.
Unfortunately, their posture is often derisive.
But when the members of this House, by force of work and conviction, assert an argued position, when
As we defend what seems to be a European general interest in the face of crisp states, the situation is changing completely.
In this debate on European supervision, Parliament has played this role.
With regard to the European Committee on Systemic Risk, of which I am the fictitious rapporteur for my group, I have defended, like the rapporteur, Mrs Goulard, an ambitious line.
I have advocated mechanisms to ensure a certain efficiency and I have insisted on the preeminence of the European Central Bank.
Why?
Because the European Central Bank is the only Community institution in this whole area and because it has shown its seriousness.
For the sake of Christian charity, I will withhold the names of all the institutions and all these great figures who suddenly disappeared during the storm.
We can be happy to have had at least one captain on board at the height of the crisis.
I will therefore be reassured to see tomorrow macro-prudential surveillance backed up by a strong Community institution, whereas micro-prudential surveillance will inevitably remain fragmented.
Having been disturbed, the European Committee on Systemic Risk must get to work as soon as possible.
The future will show whether developments will be necessary, but it is essential to start on a sound basis, as systemic risks affect the entire European and global banking sector.
Mr President, the final agreement reached on the revision of the directives on industrial emissions is more than acceptable and I welcome the compromise work that has been achieved.

This final package takes up the key points of the position which I defended with several of my colleagues in the Committee on the Environment and which aimed to make this text an ambitious but realistic legislation.
Firstly, the maintenance of a certain degree of flexibility for the companies and the competent authorities for granting derogations.
Secondly, I would like to welcome the new version of the ESN, which is so controversial and which, from now on, limited to certain sectors, seems much more feasible.

It is also important to emphasise that the agreement reached allows for better articulation with the ETS Directive and definitively removes from the text of the new Directive the irrelevant idea of creating a CO2 and NOx quota market.
A few soft words, however, and more particularly the provisions relating to the soil.
Since the SOL Directive is still pending, this important issue will unfortunately only be dealt with by the Member States which have their own legislation.
Tomorrow Parliament is due to adopt the elements of the agreement reached at the end of the trilogues.

A tremendous amount of work has been done on all sides to avoid the referral of this conciliation text, a text which, I must remind you, is of crucial importance both for industry and for European environmental policy.
Madam President, every day brings its share of information which shows us the extent of the ecological catastrophe caused in the Gulf of Mexico by the breakup of the offshore platform.
But let us not forget that other disasters of this kind occur elsewhere.
I am thinking in particular of what is happening today and for a long time in Nigeria.

That is why, in addition to the moratorium on new drilling, I believe that there is a need to promote stricter rules on the management of platforms, not only European rules but also international rules.
As far as the European Union is concerned, I think it is necessary to provide itself with a preventive way of combating this disaster, and I think it is obvious.
I also believe that all of this calls, as Mrs Damanaki has said, for a firm and resolute choice in favour of clean and renewable energy.
The European Union should set an example in this area.

Mr President, Commissioner, the reopening of negotiations with Mercosur, while the European Union is preparing to redefine its agricultural policy, reveals a dangerous lack of coherence on the part of the Commission.
Europe already imports 500 tonnes of beef.
A new opening of our market would be at the expense of farmers in disadvantaged European areas, without any guarantee of compliance with health and social standards.
We cannot accept it.
Europe is buying 38 million tonnes of soybeans and livestock feed.
These imports from Brazil and Argentina monopolize more than 19 million hectares.
They are concentrated in the hands of three companies: Cargill, ADM and Bunch.
Between 2001 and 2004, the Soya destroyed more than 1.2 million hectares of tropical and equatorial forests.
This was one of the main causes of the increase in greenhouse gas emissions and the disappearance of biodiversity.
The European Parliament has decided to produce a report on the recovery of vegetable protein autonomy for livestock feed.
Environmental agriculture and the fight against climate change dictate this choice.
These efforts will be reduced to nothing by this draft bilateral agreement.
Once again, the European Commission is bragging about its agriculture and its farmers in order to obtain random counterparts for service companies.
These concessions will not serve the peasant families of Mercosur, but the interests of agro-industrial groups.
To convince yourself of this, all you have to do is read the report by the Tyson Group, an American company that is a heavyweight in the international meat market.
which announces that it has invested in Brazil to use this country as an export platform for Europe.
Other companies, such as the company Dou, had already anticipated this approach by buying the Brazilian group Frango Sul in 1998.
Many poultry farmers, particularly in Brittany, had paid for this operation.
Europe, without wanting to pursue its policy of relocation, is amplifying its attacks.
Against the peasants, we must stop.
Mr President, many colleagues are concerned about the consequences for European agriculture of the reopening of negotiations on an association agreement with Mercosur.
My group and I share these concerns.

It is to be feared, and as a Member from an outermost region, I have experience of banana agreements, so it is to be feared that an agreement with Mercosur will have a difficult impact on many European agricultural sectors.
That is why an impact study is absolutely necessary.

It is also to be feared that this agreement will further, a little too much, turn Mercosur's agriculture towards a productivist agriculture at the expense of small farms that exist in these countries.
A balance must therefore be found so that this agreement does not transform the Latin American and European continents into superpowers anchored essentially on the dogma of mercantilism.
Mr President, I would simply like to say that we may not have done our agenda well today.
If we allow free trade agreements to enter the territory of Europe, products which do not comply with our social and environmental standards, the reform of the CAP will be useless.
In a very clear way, we cannot remain in a hypocrisy where, on the one hand, we impose environmental constraints on traceability, health and safety.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has already made a number of proposals to the Council and the European Parliament on this subject.
The question that is raised behind the negotiations with Mercosur is this.

The way things have been initiated, no matter what we are told about the fact that Parliament has been very well informed and that things have gone in the greatest transparency and the greatest clarity, does not lead us to give a positive assessment of a negotiation which is taking place while the negotiations at the WTO are continuing.
In the name of consistency, of defending consumers and defending our farmers, I do not think we should continue on this path.
Madam President, I would also like to welcome the work done by the rapporteur, Mr Jos√© Bov√©, the Commissioner and then the speech by Mr De√ü, who preceded me, on the objectives of this report.

I think it is very important to bear in mind that in the debate we are having we have to solve a problem related to the volatility of prices in agriculture and, above all, to the fact that when prices
As prices increase, they are very quickly affected at the level of distribution, but when prices fall at the level of production, there is no impact on consumers.
So there is a problem of the organization of the sector, there is a problem of the distribution of what is called added value within the sector.

I think that the Jos√© Bov√© report offers, on several points, perspectives which must be put forward and I am really addressing the Commission to try to get out of this fundamentally negative spiral.
The first, of course, is the organization of the sector and the balance of power within the sector.
What are the proposals we are making for producers, when they are assembled and organised, to have more weight in the industry to negotiate?
This is the question you raised, Commissioner, but it is also a question on the contractual basis which is going to be put in place.
I am advocating and trying in the report that this contractual basis should have a European framework.
We cannot let each country solve this problem.
There must be a European framework.
It has to be flexible, but it has to exist.
It's a proposal, a clue that I can't disassociate myself from.
Secondly, of course, the question of price transparency.
In this connection, I am in favour of the establishment of this observatory, which is absolutely necessary in order to inform consumers of price developments.
So I support the proposals that have been made and I hope, as Mr Desch said, that there will be a majority.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to welcome this debate which once again highlights the need for the Union to appreciate and value its regional diversity.
In this year of negotiations on the new 2014 framework programmes, it seems important to me to emphasise the arrangements that specific regions must benefit from.
The issues of continuity and territorial cohesion must be at the heart of our concerns.
But the development of mountainous, island or sparsely populated territories requires more than a set of derogatory measures.
We need a horizontal approach.
We must put in place the instruments capable of coexisting in synergy all areas of Community action in order to strengthen their added value.
Moreover, as a representative of the outermost regions, I look forward to the Union's new strategy for the WFP, which the Commission's services have promised us for the beginning of 2011.
Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I agree with my colleague on the Council's absence from this meeting of Parliament.
I think this is a bit of a departure from the Council's position, and I would also like to say that.
As the next summit on 6 October approaches, China and the European Union must absolutely and resolutely try to move forward together on the issue of climate change.
Last year, at the same time, we were already busy in this same House urging Europe to do everything possible to achieve an ambitious and binding agreement in Copenhagen.
We have seen that the result has not lived up to our hopes and ambitions.
So the worries a year later are the same, or even much more vivid.

So in order to be able to compel or convince our partners today, we must show that our determination is absolutely intact, show, for example, that we are giving ourselves the means to honour our commitments to the countries of the South.
For this, the introduction of innovative financing, and I heard President Sarkozy's speech to the UN yesterday, becomes a necessary proof.
So, for example, the introduction of a carbon tax at our borders is not to be excluded.

It would act as an incentive mechanism for countries that do not go far enough in their commitment to climate, much more than a threat in the end, and a way to protect our jobs and our businesses, especially to better address the aftermath of the crisis.

Madam President, for me the need to revalue family leave is not to be proved. Raising the minimum threshold for maternity leave is an advance, a benefit, and we must not be totally demagogic in comparing the economic impact with the hardly quantifiable qualitative benefits.

But the problem is essentially two-fold: first, the economic context, which is true, but not enough to leave millions of families behind for decades; second, the legal loopholes in the report, because the text contains several types of family leave whose legal basis is not conciliable.
Let us take the adoption leave, which is in the text under the same title as maternity and paternity leave.
I personally appreciate, as an adoptive mother and for all those I embody, the willingness to give the same rights as biological mothers.
I am, in fact, the little extra package that Mrs Morin was talking about, added to the Estrela report.

If the aim is to strengthen the health and rights of women, of all women in the labour market, then adoptive women who have become mothers in the same capacity as others are entitled to the same rights and the same protection at work.
They are mothers like the others, in part, and they adopt a child over or under 12 months old, and there is no discrimination, please, as they are mentioned in the text.
As far as adoption is concerned, I regret that the text has been so inadequate.
It wasn't even fueled by the Rembolz impact study.
All of this is not well-finished, which is clearly a weak point.

Nevertheless, despite these difficulties, I will support Mrs Estrela's report because, beyond economic considerations, there are men and women who must not only better assume their parental responsibilities in a society of

We are becoming more and more resigned to the education of these young people, but also because it is our duty to ensure that no one has to choose between sacrificing their children for their work or sacrificing their work for their children.
Finally, we are not sitting in the Council, but in Parliament, and if we direct elected representatives are not ambitious, tell me who will be.
Madam President, Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to speak and not go back to the debate as it has been going on so far.

We have discussed a 2011 budget with the constraints that we know, that is to say, those of a deep crisis that Europe is going through, with public deficits at national level, which can lead to two hypotheses.
Do these public deficits at national level constrain the European deficit, or do these national deficits have to give a new direction and a new breath to Europe?
That's the question.
I ask you, Commissioner, above all to try to think, when we are discussing a budgetary revision, when we are going to start talking about the budgetary prospects for the year after 2013, not to
It has to remain totally imbued with the context of the crisis, except to tell me and to tell all the citizens of Europe that Europe will definitely remain in the crisis for a long time.
Our whole problem is indeed to manage the crisis and to reduce our deficits and our debt, but it is also to prepare for the exit from the crisis.
And that is where the budgetary question comes in.

We will only be able to get out of the crisis, and this was said by Joseph Daul right away, if the European budget, because it is European, is able to give us the means to get back what we are missing today, growth, job creation, innovation, research.

That is the issue and it is at this level that we must discuss the budget and not, as we do all too often, constantly integrate the question of the crisis, the question of the deficits, and the Council is excellent.

I noted that in Douville, Angela Merkel and Nicolas Sarkozy even announced in advance a reform of the Treaties, without even discussing anything with Mr Van Rompuy, in order to punish all the States which would not respect budgetary discipline tomorrow.
That is where we are at Council level today, whereas Parliament is asking for only one thing, and in particular the Commission, to try to draw the European project, and that is through the budget.
You have noted a number of things on which we are in complete agreement.
We need more flexibility.
It is clear that we must be able to find, together, the capacity to have a much more flexible budget, because it is the reactivity of Europe that is at stake.
It is also, of course, a question of setting priorities and organising the efficiency of the European budget.
We'll all agree on that. We'll all agree. It's a necessity.

But where we have to be clear with each other is that we have to have a calendar, we have to set goals together, Commissioner, and it can only be words, it can only be commitments, it can only be goals.

These texts are very interesting and I share them practically 100 percent, but now we have to go into the concrete and, in particular, on an essential issue around which we are turning, which is own resources.
How do we get our own resources for Europe tomorrow, not for Europe, but for all European citizens, and how do we get back together on the path of growth and a stronger path for Europe?
It's up to you, Commissioner.
Mr President, I would like to focus on the preparations for the next G20 summits.

Everything has been said by the previous speakers about European economic governance, about the need to strengthen European economic governance, to strengthen the Stability and Growth Pact and to better involve the European Parliament and, of course, the national parliaments in the process.
I would like to mention briefly two challenges facing our nations and the members of the G20 which, in my view, must be dealt with in the context of the next G20 meetings.
the challenge of the currency war and the volatility of commodity prices.
I think that on these two subjects, which are real threats to global growth and which cause very important imbalances on our planet, the Union must

The European Union is able to organise itself, to take common positions, to give itself the means to speak with one voice at the next G20 summits in Seoul, but also at the ones to follow, and more generally on the world stage.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to congratulate our colleague, Mr Diogo Feio, on the quality of the report and on the ambitious proposal it contains.
So it also shows that the European Parliament is taking its full place in a debate which is decisive for the future of Europe, and we can only congratulate ourselves on that.
Moreover, the Greek crisis has been a revealer of the dysfunctions that undermine the economic governance of the European Union.
I take note of Mr Feio's proposal to set up a permanent mechanism for financial stability.
We must also tackle the root of the problem.
For this reason, I believe that the solution also lies in strengthening the Stability and Growth Pact, in particular sanctions.
This is essential if we are to achieve a lasting improvement in the budgetary situation of the Member States, which is not always popular.
It's constraining, but we don't have a choice.

Mr President, I believe that the report shows well the challenges facing the marine environment in terms of fisheries, aquaculture, transport, tourism, energy, mineral and biological wealth, and research in combination with climate change.
This is a considerable potential for development which must be safeguarded, protected and put into practice in the long term, because the future of humanity depends on it.
The report also rightly notes that the European Union is the world's leading maritime power and that its outermost regions offer it the largest exclusive economic zone in the world.
In view of this, it is therefore up to the European Union to implement an ambitious policy, a major maritime policy.
If it is not the world's first maritime power, who will do it instead?
But it is clear that the resolution does not go very far in this direction.
It is not with 50 million euros that one can claim to occupy the leadership position in world politics.
Finally, while the outermost regions have a recognised strategic position, since they are present in all the oceans, they have a
It was wise to have them play a major role in a great strategy for the oceans, which unfortunately was not included in the report and I regret that.
Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to return to the anti-counterfeiting agreement which is currently being negotiated, particularly with the United States.
This agreement raises questions in the United States as well, especially among officials of the American Patent Office.
In addition, 75 American law professors have just sent a letter to President Obama.
They believe that ACTA, a simple executive agreement, would be contrary to the American Constitution.
While the European Parliament is preparing, as you know, to adopt a resolution on the ACTA agreement, it is still raising serious concerns and is far from unanimous.
I think it would be useful to have a very clear answer from our American interlocutors on two points.
In their view, is ACTA a binding or voluntary agreement?
Indeed, an anti-counterfeiting agreement, which China, India and Brazil are already absent from, which would not be implemented by the United States, would lose much of its credibility.
Thank you very much.

Mr President, throughout this difficult birth of the Alternative Funds Directive, I have consistently advocated the principle of equal treatment between fund managers, whether they are from the European Union or not.
This principle sounds obvious, but its obviousness has encountered innumerable difficulties.
The result presented to us today is satisfactory.
I thank the negotiators and, above all, our rapporteur, Mr Gozes, who, after this particularly painful delivery for him, would deserve a substantial maternity leave.
I would like to emphasize above all that the issue of the treatment of third countries must nevertheless be observed in two ways, whether within or outside the European Union.
Thanks in particular to the European Parliament, all funds sold in the European Union will actually be subject to comparable regulation.
We can therefore more or less talk about the level playing field.

It remains that during the transitional period non-European Union entities will benefit from the national placement scheme, while European Union funds and managers will be subject to the directive, which is generally stricter.
The situation is different in the markets outside the European Union, where European funds and their managers will remain subject to the directive, which is not the case for third-country funds.
It would therefore be much more difficult to sell European products to the rest of the world because they would be less flexible and more expensive.
We must be aware of this disadvantage, even if it was inevitable on the one hand.
As far as depositors are concerned, we know that we will make the exercise more binding, in particular because of the new responsibilities which will burden them.

Mr President, I am not saying this to show my opposition, but to indicate that this new regulation has nothing to do with us, and its implementation, which is necessary, will also entail difficulties which must be borne in mind.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, especially at the beginning of the 21st century, patients need appropriate information in order to be fully involved in the care process, to know where to seek care, to decide on the best treatment in agreement with health professionals and to follow the prescribed treatment.
Today, patients demand independent, comparative and tailored information for their needs.
Unfortunately, the proposals for the revision of the directive transmitted by the European Commission did not respond correctly to the needs expressed by European citizens.
These proposals opened the door to direct promotion by pharmaceutical companies, which seems to us to be nonsense in terms of responding to the real needs of patients.
This operation is of no interest to citizens or Member States.
On the contrary, it meant additional bureaucracy, an increase in expenditure and risk to patients.
It is for these reasons that we first put forward a proposal to reject these texts, and asked the Commission to review its copy.
This approach, also adopted by my colleague Carl Schilter of the Green Group, has enabled our rapporteur, Mr Feischner, whom I welcome, to make an important revision of the Commission's proposals.

At the same time, we had tabled some 60 amendments aimed at better protecting the health of our citizens and facilitating patients' access to independent, comparative and tailored information for their needs.

The adoption of these amendments in the Committee on the Environment has made it possible to place more emphasis on the rights of patients to information rather than making the provision of information an option for the pharmaceutical industry.

In the light of the compromise amendments obtained, we have decided to withdraw our proposal to reject the texts and the substance of the text, which has evolved in the right direction in recent months.
The draft report, as amended, has succeeded in counterbalancing the European Commission's initial proposals.

However, we will continue to refuse to allow health professionals to be instrumentalized to distribute to their patients leaflets and information provided by pharmaceutical companies without any control by the health authorities.
Similarly, we will oppose the authorization of industrial information campaigns, particularly in the field of vaccination.
Information cannot come freely from pharmaceutical companies.

Experience shows that we must be very vigilant, and I conclude that what has happened with the mediator medicines shows how vigilant we must be and ensure that this point of balance, as we have sought with this draft report, is maintained.
Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, Union and realism will be declined, at least I hope so, in tomorrow's vote on our resolution on this 16th Conference of the Parties on Climate Change.

I hope that our Commissioner in charge will be able to achieve the pragmatic objectives which we will have to achieve collectively, but also to defend the conditions which Europe has set and which are associated with them.
In these negotiations, we must also not lose sight of the legitimate expectations of fairness of our fellow citizens and our industries.
It is the world that must fight climate change, not Europe alone.
Thus, recognizing the importance of intellectual property that is too poorly protected will be essential.
Green technologies must benefit as many people as possible, but we must not, however, waste our present and future knowledge, even in this indispensable fight against climate change.

Similarly, asking for common emission calculation methods, as well as verification and publication of data, so that all emitting industries are subject to the same bargaining, seems to be a most legitimate request and not a negotiating weapon.
Finally, more controversial and my colleague raised it earlier, the shortcomings of the current system of clean development mechanisms will also have to be put on the table.
Ladies and gentlemen, we are all well aware, unfortunately, that the real negotiating power is not held by the European Parliament.

But the will of many Members of the European Parliament, of whom I am one, to work and to participate in a positive outcome of this conference must be encouraged and not neglected, as we have been able to feel in the last few days.
If Europe wants to be strong in international dialogues, it must be the same for all its legislators.
Madam President, the European Union often presents economic partnership agreements as an opportunity for African countries.
So she despairs of not seeing these agreements signed as soon as possible.
But the question we have to ask is why these countries are not rushing to sign agreements that would be so favourable to them.
Clearly, there are differences of opinion on the quality of these agreements, and as long as these differences of opinion persist, the ACP countries will be reluctant to sign them.
Should we not go further in dialogue and understanding by listening to the concerns and expectations of the ACP countries?
They want to talk about development strategies, whereas Europe often responds only by opening up markets.
It is this listening that the ACP-EU Parliamentary Assembly is imposing itself on.
I think that the other European bodies should do the same if we are to build a real strategic partnership between Africa and the European Union.
Mr President, Christians are undoubtedly one of the most persecuted religious groups in the world.

In the Middle East, they are perceived by some extremist groups as legitimate targets and the objective is their pure and simple departure from this region, a region that saw the birth of Christianity and in which their historical presence is necessary for a certain balance.
The events at Baghdad Cathedral are only the culmination of a situation which we have been passively observing for far too long.
The European Union, as a global player and trading partner of many countries in the region, must express its strong indignation at the situation.
Discrimination, whatever it may be, cannot be tolerated.
Democracy will only be victorious in this region when the most fundamental human rights, such as religious freedom, are respected.
Ladies and gentlemen, we are all concerned about the serious crisis currently raging in C√¥te d'Ivoire.

It is clear that the decision of the Constitutional Council of that country to challenge, in violation of the electoral code, the results of the elections officially proclaimed by the Independent Electoral Commission is unanimously condemned by the international community.

The European Union, the UN, the African Union, the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, the ECOWAS and, soon, certainly the European Parliament, are calling for respect for the official proclamation of the
the results of the elections and the installation of the new President of the Republic, as recognised by the Independent Electoral Commission, which, I remind you, is a body validated by the UN.
All the political groups in the European Parliament have expressed their agreement on these essential points in a joint statement.

They also called for the end of any escalation of tensions in the country that could lead to civil war, which would be a human, social and economic disaster for C√¥te d'Ivoire, which must of course be avoided at all costs.

Madam President, I would like to thank our four rapporteurs who have done remarkable work and who have given the European Parliament a great deal of added value to the text originally proposed by the Commission.
The citizens' initiative which we, the EPP, are preparing to vote enthusiastically is a major step forward in the Lisbon Treaty.
Let us not be mistaken, this instrument can really change the European political landscape, if it is used with both responsibility and audacity.
It can help to bring European citizens directly into the European political debate.
It can help to raise European public opinion, that is to say, men and women, citizens of Europe, who debate together, who take a stand together and come together on truly European subjects.
But let's not disappoint our fellow citizens.
Let us urge our Member States to take swift enforcement measures where necessary, not to disappoint our fellow citizens, but to strengthen European democracy.
Mr President, I too, like many of my colleagues, wanted to address the question of the persecution of Christians all over the world, especially Christians in the East.
No one needs to recall the horrible acts recently committed.
I would like to recall very solemnly that we must defend Christians in the East, as in the rest of the world, and advocate for religious freedom and diversity.

To defend these beliefs is to advocate freedom, democracy and human rights, which are values at the heart of the European project and which are, of course, in any case, we are all convinced of here, universal values.
It is really time now, beyond indignation, emotion and solemn condemnation, of course, to put words into action.
I therefore urge the authorities of the European Union, the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, but also all our governors, the Foreign Ministers.
We must take concrete measures, put in place a concrete action plan to make respect for religious diversity and the fight against all forms of religious persecution a priority.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam High Representative, we all agree that the situation in the Sahel region has deteriorated considerably.
And allowing a no-go zone to be set up at the gates of Europe is a danger that we must fight firmly and without delay.
Extremist groups are multiplying and threatening the lives of civilians.
In turn, I deplore the loss of life and the taking of hostages and I am concerned about the European citizens on the ground.
Until now, Morocco has been a bulwark against trafficking of all kinds from the Sahel.
Now drug, arms and human traffickers bypass Morocco by passing through Mauritania to the Canary Islands in the direction of the European Union.
It seems to me that it is the responsibility of the European Union to act to help these States put an end to these threats.
Europe's security is at stake not only on our territory but also in its immediate neighbourhood.
It is time for us to act and I ask the Commission and the Council to implement an action plan to help bring security back to the Sahel.
That has been said, but I associate myself with the signs of sympathy and support which have already been expressed towards the Tunisian and Egyptian peoples.
It is a symbol of hope for all defenders of freedom.
A thought for the victims too.

I would now like to say that the European Union, which has been noted for its lack of reaction, must be on the side of the Tunisian and Egyptian peoples to help them to bring about the opening up of their country to reform and to establish democracy.

The European Union has decided to accompany the Tunisian leaders to engage in a peaceful transition, prepare the organisation of the upcoming elections to gain freedom and allow the Tunisian people to find prosperity, development and social peace, an economy that will allow young people to find employment.

I would like to conclude by saying that the Union for the Mediterranean faces an important challenge because the Jasmine Revolution has triggered a wave in all the states of the Maghreb, the Middle East and the Middle East.
It must put in place a strong strategy towards these countries.

But beware, in the face of this legitimate democratic movement, Europe must find a balance between non-interference in internal affairs, support for the legitimate aspirations of the peoples and stability.
Commissioner, my colleagues have repeatedly reminded me of this.

At a time when Europe is wondering about a common strategy for its supply of raw materials, particularly in rare earths, we cannot ignore the enormous potential of the intelligent valuation of our waste.

Strengthening European standards to improve the functioning of the collection sectors, addressing the problem of leakage or illegal export of waste or increasing our collection targets must also be at the heart of this legislation.
Let us not forget the main actor in the success or failure of this regulation, the consumer.
Citizen accountability is crucial if we are to put in place effective legislation.
To this end, my dear Carlin, eco-contribution, among other systems, has proved to be one of the most relevant tools.

Of course, manufacturers of electrical and electronic equipment must be more involved in the collection and recycling system, but the citizen cannot be exempted from customs duties on the waste they produce.
Our citizens must be actors and not spectators of European environmental policy.
Madam President, Mr President, Commissioner, I would first of all like to share Mrs McGuinness's remark that there is an essential link between the food issue and the agricultural issue.
The issue we are concerned about is the increase in food prices, with the consequences that this can have for a number of people in the world, but also in Europe.
I would first like to try to make a statement.

The trend towards rising agricultural prices and agricultural commodities is a long-term trend for me and will continue for three main reasons: the demographic evolution of the world and the increase in
The second element is the fact that we have entered, with global warming, into climate disruptions that are causing problems, whether it's drought or flooding.
With new emerging countries, consumption levels are rising.
So the tension over agricultural markets and agricultural commodities is a heavy trend.
It is aggravated by price volatility and price volatility is a consequence of the financialisation of the global economy.
It is also on this subject that we must attack if we are to resolve both the agricultural and the food issues.

To do this, as the Commissioner has said, it is important that there are two elements: yes, there is a need for transparency on stocks, but there is also a need for a public stock policy in Europe and for global stock management, particularly at UN level.

Secondly, there is a need to regulate financial markets and financial speculation, in particular by refusing to allow speculative volumes to have any connection with the physical quantities exchanged on the markets.
We cannot accept that speculators come to speculate on the food issue without taking into account the consequences that this may have, since it is the food of the world and of humanity.
Because this brings me to two major consequences we need a strong European policy and we strategically reaffirm Europe's commitment to being a global food and agricultural player.
Secondly, we need to change our development policy to ensure that, on a global scale, and Europe is an actor, we invest again in agriculture, because we will need all agriculture to feed the world.
Madam President, Commissioner, as in 2008, the price of agricultural raw materials is rising on world markets.
We're only three percent of the level of 2008.
The decline in production in some traditional exporting areas due to climate change, the diversion of cereals through the production of agrofuels and speculation
The financial institutions that have accidentally had an increase in their profits are responsible for this situation, as the reports of the IMF, the French authorities and the Commission show.
The consequences of this new food crisis hit hard the 1.2 billion people in the world who live on less than a dollar a day.
Since October, 44 million more people have joined those living below the poverty line.
Two days before the G20 meeting, what is Europe waiting for to take measures similar to those voted in the United States?
Since 13 January 2011, the US administration has demanded the limitation and transparency of the positions taken by the financial funds on the agricultural commodity markets.
This advance is the first step to counteract the appetites of speculators.
The impact is also dramatic for European farmers.
They are no longer able to feed their animals.
Hundreds of farms are bankrupt.
Five years ago, wheat was worth 100 euros a tonne, but today it is being traded for almost 300 euros.
So the don has completely changed.
The Commission is demanding that farmers adapt to market signals, and it would be well inspired today to follow its own advice.
Faced with this crisis, the European Union cannot wait until 2014 to find solutions.
We must face up to the crisis, and I propose three concrete actions.
Firstly, the creation of stocks in cereal-producing countries to make farmers available at subsidised prices immediately.
Secondly, the indexation of the prices of meat paid to farmers on the evolution of the course of livestock feed.
Thirdly, for 2011, a mechanism for the transfer of part of the aid for the support of cereals to animal production.
Mr President, are we in Europe ready to face a pandemic?
The answer is yes, but there is a may.
The 2009 H1N1 influenza outbreak showed us that each Member State reacted on its own, without much consistency or even solidarity.

As a fictitious rapporteur on this matter, I think we should have made these findings, but above all we should have gone further, been constructive, concrete for our citizens, who, it must be said, and this is what seems to me the most damaging thing, have probably lost some confidence in the public health messages.

Mrs Rivasi's report, which will be voted on tomorrow, takes account of these fundamental priorities, which include, among other things, the systematic strengthening of cooperation between Member States and better coordination with the Member States.

the European health institutions, a clarification of the roles of the European health risk management structures, an evaluation of the vaccination and communication strategies implemented in the Member States.
So it is a good report, and I congratulate the rapporteur, but it must not be left as a dead letter.
It is the responsibility of our Member States, which retain the bulk of the competences in this area, and it is therefore a real responsibility to our citizens.
Mr President, it is my turn to express my deepest condolences after the cowardly murder on 2 March of the Pakistani minister in charge of Christian minorities, Mr Bati.
This terrorist murder follows many other murders of courageous, tolerant Pakistanis, lovers of human rights, defenders of human rights and women's rights, I must say.

Once again, we urge the Pakistani government to shed light on this cowardly murder and to ensure effectively, really effectively, the protection of people threatened by fanatical religious extremists.
I am thinking, of course, first and foremost, but not only, of Mrs. Sherry Rehmann.
I would also like to ask once again, with all my strength, all the competent institutions of the European Union to include in the negotiations the following:
We must prepare the future cooperation agreements, in particular the cooperation agreement between the EU and Pakistan, a clause on respect for religious freedom and respect for human rights.
Mr President, as a reminder, with the crisis and the explosion of the real estate and credit bubble, the Irish State had to intervene to support the banks.
Ireland's public deficit, the cumulative budgetary balance of central, local and, in particular, social security administrations, was estimated at 32% of gross domestic product in 2010.

If the Irish Government, which is unable to refinance itself at the market, wishes to access loans from the Mechanism and the European Financial Stability Fund, it will have to meet social and tax change obligations, whereas these areas are subsidiary.
In our sense, it is not antinomic.
As a doctor, I would say that in the case of fever, there is no point in prescribing antipyretic drugs blindly without seeking to treat the cause.
In the event of the allocation of these funds, it is up to this State to clean up its finances in order to make up for its excessive deficit and correct its previous mistakes.
This austerity plan should improve GDP by 10% over the next four years.

In the same way that a bank, without being involved in its own life and private management, will condition its personal loan to a solvency guarantee, so too can the European Union lend to Ireland on the basis of consolidated solvency.
Without interfering with its private management, the bank will encourage the individual to negotiate, for example, a wage increase or to borrow elsewhere.

Thus, by respecting subsidiarity, the European Union, on the basis of a memorandum with the IMF, considers that this solvency is achieved by reducing the legal minimum wage and adjusting pensions, without exempting itself from tax measures.
I ask Ireland to choose whether or not to implement these measures.

It is not the open door to European Union interference in the field of subsidiarity, which would, for example, dangerously impose a European minimum wage, but the protection of the stability of the euro area through a process of mutual guarantee.

It is, of course, necessary to help Ireland, as well as other countries in difficulty, which also protects us, but not at any cost, namely to see a State unable to repay on time, thus weakening its citizens and those of the whole of the European Union.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the eruption of the Icelandic volcano last April, as many of us have said before, is a painful illustration of the fragmentation and inefficiency of the European sky.
And each of us in this House has been directly involved.
Five million of our fellow citizens have been left without a real alternative transport solution.
A year after this exceptional event, new European measures are still awaited.

Mr President, as you said, Commissioner, a first crisis exercise on volcanic ash is well planned for the next 13 and 14 April, under the coordination of the Eurocontrol of the OACI and the IATA, but it is essential that the EASA takes a real leadership role in coordinating security measures at European level.
It is certain that the information provided by the VACs in London and Toulouse must be refined using more modern technological means.
However, these data, as we saw last April, can be contradictory and can lead each Member State to take decisions on the closure of its airspace, less motivated by information than by emotion.
In this context, the role of the ESA is essential to propose a harmonised interpretation of this data and to ensure the centralisation and proper dissemination of information.
In addition to VAC information, the EASA should set up a mechanism for collecting the available data by closely associating Member States, airlines and their pilots.
This centralisation of information and the coordination of all the actors concerned will help to avoid the chaos and inconsistencies we witnessed last year.
I therefore expect the Commission, together with the ESA, to be able to present quickly concrete proposals which will be fully integrated into the implementation of the single European sky.
Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this text is important.
It's not a revolution, we can't say that everything was bad before and that everything is perfect now.
But nevertheless, it presents a number of major advances at this provisional stage of our work.
The main ones, in my view, concern better control of sales by remote and in particular on the Internet, and that is chapter three, because we need to strengthen consumer rights in this area.
E-commerce is very useful, it expands the consumer's choice, it allows him to get the lowest prices and it also allows small and medium-sized enterprises and craftsmen to find new outlets.

In order to make progress in this area, it was necessary to do so in a truly European way, that is to say, on a few very targeted points, to put in place a complete harmonization of the rights and duties of each individual.
Very concretely, an Italian customer who buys on a Belgian site or on a German site should know that from now on he will have the same rights, the same protection.
That is what this directive will make possible.
This means that its withdrawal period will be extended by 14 days throughout the Union.
This means that he will know right away the total of what he will have to pay, without fear of a bad surprise after the blow.
This means that, thanks to the double click, he will check his order correctly.
Obviously, all of this is going to shake up some habits.
In many countries there are subtleties in national law which everyone is convinced are fundamental, whereas sometimes we do not even find a trace of them in neighbouring countries.
But living together in Europe is learning to change these habits a little bit in the service of the Community and the general interest.
Let us be clear, this text will have to be improved further and we will have to do so in the coming weeks, with the Council and with the Commission.
I appreciated the openings that have just been made in this regard.
But we have already done a substantial amount of work thanks to our rapporteur, Andreas Schwab, to whom I warmly thank.
But the real fruit of this work is above all the fact that the amendments will be voted on tomorrow by all the political groups.
Consumers' confidence in the Union's internal market is very fragile.
This political unanimity was needed to preserve it and to hope to strengthen it.
Point 7 After the first paragraph, a first point to be drawn is to ensure respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, in particular the right to freedom of expression.
Freedom of speech and assembly, and the right to peaceful demonstration and to listen to and take into account the legitimate demands of the protesters and ensure their safety.

Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the open-ended agreement between Europe and the United States is an advance, but it is only a step, a step that puts Europe in the face of a dilemma.
The Committee on Transport and the Commission itself have stressed this.
Either we accept an agreement that disadvantages European companies, or we suspend the agreement and risk losing the profits gained since 2008.

Allow me then to draw a parallel with the licences of private and professional pilots, a text which will be discussed before the summer, because the pilots, of whom I am one, are faced with a dilemma.
The European Aviation Safety Agency, wishing to harmonise licences on European territory, will do so at the expense of the 90 general aviation pilots.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so, what is the Commission's position?
I would like to draw your attention to this project, which has no security basis.
There are 31 times fewer accidents among U.S. license holders.
The objectives of the basic regulation text 216 allow for the recognition and equivalence of licences, which do not see the interest in waiting for hypothetical agreements postponed to 2014.
So I propose a very open-ended agreement and even invite you to accompany me when I sometimes come to Parliament by flying myself to show you that an American pilot's license is quite safe.
Madam President, at this stage of our debate I will inevitably be forced to repeat or support some of the things that have been said before.
But I also wanted to say that, like many of my colleagues, the problems we have to face, which the whole of the European Union has to face at the moment, cannot be solved by any Member State alone.
No Member State should be left alone in the face of the challenges it faces and which, once again, in my view, face the whole of the European Union.
It is therefore really the capacity of the European Union to organise itself and to deal with the situation in a common and solidarity-based manner that I am calling for.
I believe that the time has really come now to set the bar for a genuine European immigration and asylum policy.
More than a year ago, a European asylum and immigration pact was adopted.
The time has come now, I think, to decline it in a very concrete way.
We have heard, Madam Commissioner, we have heard a number of the recommendations she has made.
I wanted to come back to this and strongly support some of these proposals.
Yes, the resources of the Frontex Agency must be strengthened at all costs.
We must strengthen the human, material and financial resources of the Frontex Agency, enabling it to support Hermes and Poseidon operations more effectively.
Yes, additional financial resources are needed for the Member States which are faced, I would say, first and foremost with the acute migration flows we are experiencing today.
And it will be the financial expression of our solidarity.
Yes, we need to establish closer cooperation relations with the countries on the southern shore of the Mediterranean, to accompany them, of course, to help them, to find instruments.
The Commissioner was referring, I believe, to the mobility partnerships which she visited Tunisia to discuss.
Yes, we must strengthen these instruments in a spirit of responsibility, in a spirit of solidarity, but also in a precise and concrete spirit.

Mr President, Commissioner, you probably know that the closest discussions we have had here around your communication concern the place of public services, services of general interest, in the single market and their legislative translation.
We have reached a compromise which invites you to go beyond your proposal 25 and we ask you to go beyond a simple
A communication which would not meet the expectations and needs of the actors, users and all stakeholders in the public services, nor would it meet the objectives which you are also setting.
The European Union must send a clear and unambiguous message on public services.
To do this, we need to create a positive legal framework, regulation or directive.
The Treaty of Lisbon gives us the legal basis for this.
It is up to you to translate them into legislative proposals now.
I think that Parliament is ready to follow you in this direction.
Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate all the rapporteurs on their gigantic work on this discharge and I also welcome the presence of the Council in this debate.
