The seat of the European Parliament in Strasbourg is a matter of European identity and not just a matter of economy.

I am speaking about this today in this House, at the time of the debate on the 2009 discharge, because the symbol of Franco-German reconciliation is treated by some members of the Committee on Budgetary Control as a simple way of making savings.
I am also interested in the question of Parliament's expenditure.
In this connection, I propose that you hold the Group weeks in Strasbourg rather than in Brussels, which would enable us to make our Parliament's seat in Strasbourg profitable.
Since we want to save money, I propose other things, such as the removal of the Friday allowance for our colleagues and the removal of the allowance for journalists.
Europe is attractive enough that we are not obliged to give a perdiem to journalists.

Let us not hide behind the budgetary argument in order to take up an important issue which goes beyond the framework of budgetary control, and this, although I welcome the important work of our rapporteur, Mr Ville, on this discharge.
Finally, since we are talking about savings, I also want to moralise and clean up the system of compensation for groups of sponsored visitors.

I do not think it is very moral, and it gives a very bad image of our institution, that the head of the group is reimbursed in numerary terms, in kind, on the day of the visit, without any work, without any control over what the group has spent.
Sometimes the amount allocated, I'm telling you, exceeds the amount of actual expenditure.

It would be logical for the groups to send a bill to the visitor's service in advance, to receive a Parliament's account of expenditure, and this on a bank account, and to pay the balance on presentation of the invoices actually paid, with a ceiling, of course.
Madam President, I would like to address the Commission, my colleagues and the presence of the Council.
The question that arises today arises from the management of the Schengen area in 2011.

This is no longer the space of the five Member States of the 1980s, but rather a space which has continued to expand in recent years and which now includes 25 States, three of which are not members of the European Union.
Like all European policies, Schengen cooperation must therefore adapt to the reality it faces today, which is no longer the same as it was ten years ago.
It is in this sense that we must read the proposals of the Italian and French governments and the pragmatic and necessary responses given today by the Commission in its communication on immigration.
Mutual trust between the Member States in the Schengen area is certainly the cornerstone of Schengen cooperation.
But this trust is based on mutual obligations.
If one of the parties fails to comply with its obligations and creates calls for help, the whole system fails.
It must therefore be possible for other States to respond to this failure by re-establishing temporary and strictly controlled control of their borders.
In doing so, these failing states will clearly be invited to better control their external borders.

Moreover, as presented by the Commission, these measures would fully respect the spirit of Schengen, as long as these controls were reintroduced at the last minute and the decision was taken at European level and not at intergovernmental level.
Such measures will be intrinsically linked to all the measures envisaged in the long term in the perspective of a common migration policy.
In particular, it is essential to strengthen Frontex, to provide more solidarity, and I conclude by supporting the States at the external borders.
The situation in the Mediterranean in recent years has only highlighted a gap in the Schengen acquis.
Madam President, in a few weeks, migrants from the Mediterranean countries accounted for a significant percentage of annual French immigration.
This acquisition is not static, but must, on the contrary, evolve.
I hope that these proposals will be adopted swiftly, to ensure the best possible management of our Schengen area and thereby ensure the security of our common external borders.
Mr President, the European Union has finally imposed sanctions on Syria.
But unfortunately, it seems to be doing so with a trembling hand, carefully avoiding questioning the head of the Syrian regime.
This lack of determination and clarity is obviously interpreted by the protesters as a form of abandonment and by the authorities as an indulgence that allows it to intensify.
A repression so cruel that we cannot imagine for a moment that at the same time Syria can be elected to sit on the Human Rights Council of the United Nations.
The United Nations, while today the Syrian authorities are refusing UN observers access to the city of Dehra, the scene of terrible violence against defenseless civilians.

Assassination of the Human Rights Council would be an insult to the victims and their families, an encouragement for this regime to use brutal force against its people, in defiance of the values of which the Human Rights Council must be the guardian.
So, Madam High Representative, what diplomatic options do you envisage to avoid such a disaster?

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I should like first of all to congratulate my colleague, Mr Carlos Coelho, who has done a great job on this report, and God knows it was very complicated.
Bulgaria and Romania have made considerable efforts to strengthen control of their borders and have succeeded in doing so.
Whether it is police and judicial cooperation, data protection, visa policy or air, sea or land border control, the latest assessments are very clear.
All technical criteria are met.
We can only see this state of affairs.
Both Bulgaria and Romania are now able to implement this Schengen acquis in technical and personnel terms.
Moreover, although no obstacle today prevents the enlargement of the Schengen area, we note that a number of recommendations have been addressed to these two countries.

I hope that these recommendations will be closely monitored, particularly in the context of the borders between Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey, because, as you know, mutual trust between the Schengen States is based on full respect by these States of their mutual obligations.
If one of the parties fails to comply with its obligations, it creates air calls, and the whole system fails.
I very much hope that an agreement will be reached in the Council to welcome these two countries into the privileged circles formed by the Schengen States.
And we will all measure in this House the scope of this type of decision for the citizens concerned.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to congratulate Mr Coelho on his report.
Mr President, in its Europe 2020 strategy, the European Union has set itself the objective of making our economy greener and our transport more modern.
All the European institutions have largely supported this objective, including almost all the Member States and our Parliament.
In this context, it is therefore regrettable that, since 2008, several Member States have been busy emptying the new proposal for the Eurovignette Directive of its content and blocking this dossier.

Today, however, thanks to the tenacity of our rapporteur and I would like to greet here Saeed El Khadraoui, thanks to his tenacity and that of the fictitious rapporteurs in their negotiations with the Council, we finally have a compromise before us.

Although this text is much less ambitious than the initial proposal, it will make it possible for the first time to put the polluter-pays principle into practice and to internalize external transport costs such as noise or CO2 emissions.

In order for this euro to be not just a tax but to contribute effectively to the improvement of transport in Europe, Member States are also encouraged to reinvest the money collected in the modernisation of transport modes.
Parliament has also succeeded in achieving concrete progress on the interoperability of toll systems and stronger incentives for the use of less polluting heavy goods vehicles.

In order to remain consistent with the political objectives set by our institution, I sincerely hope that we will be able to adopt this compromise proposed to us at second reading and thus pave the way for a more sustainable transport policy.

Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I agree that with freedom and fraternity there should be equality with the peasants and the countries that have returned, with the countries returning from the East.
Yes, I agree with you.
I think we've made a big step forward with this report.
It was not easy at first and we were rather in a confrontation, but we came to a consensus and that is the most important thing.
This consensus makes it possible to protect the overall project, and I believe that this is the great merit of the European Parliament.
We succeeded in this bet and it was not easy, so I thank the rapporteur, Mr Mercedes, and all the Members of Parliament.
First step.
In this text we reaffirm the need for equality, justice and fairness between producers and between territories, and I think this is important.

We have made it very clear and we have confirmed the maintenance and development of small farms, the taking into account of small farms, which are essential for the quality and biodiversity of the territories.
I think it was also fundamental.
The fact that we have introduced this notion of making agriculture agronomic, of turning the page on industrial productivist agriculture, is enshrined in the texts.
It is a condition for making agriculture possible for future generations.
It's not an ideological issue.
Finally, today we are concerned that there are indeed threats to the budget.
We'll have to answer that clearly.

Now what we are waiting for is that we would actually go back to the second phase, which is clearly the legislative debate, because beyond the texts, the great intentions, it is in the legislative debate that we will really see where we are going, and that is what we are obviously waiting for now.
I would like to end by shouting out against Germany's attitude, which has led to a fivefold reduction in food aid to the poorest in Europe.
It was in the CAP budget.
I want us to find a way to help the poorest, there are 80 million European citizens who do not eat properly when they are hungry.
Mr President, as much as the European Parliament can boast of some good progress in economic governance, I urge my colleagues to show humility, because we are dancing to the bottom of the abyss.
Let us be aware of two things.
The first is that the European Parliament has remained silent in the Greek crisis.
While we are usually so quick to react to all sorts of events at the expense of solutions all over the world, this existential crisis seems to leave us without a way out.
I very much regret that we have been unable to send a strong, concrete, simple message to the Greeks, to the governments of the Member States and to the citizens of Europe.
The second finding is within the scope of this package.
By voting on what I want, these six directives or regulations, we will certainly make the euro area a step forward.
One more step towards a discipline we have so missed, one more step, I say, which will show its usefulness in the future.
But it is only to see the heated discussions around the overturned qualified majority to measure the path we have left to follow, when it should be about automatic rules and sanctions.
The mechanism of the overturned qualified majority continues to act on some as a nightmare.
We must, however, remain firm on the principle.
On a strictly political level, I regret that the left-wing parties continue to reject the principles of good budgetary management, against all odds.
Yes, deficits and sustainable growth are antinomic.
Yes, states must also manage their budgets in good faith, but not by relocating public spending.
While the next few weeks are crucial, today it is a matter of re-establishing an economic union.
We voted this morning, after three years of work, on a very important text for the progress of consumer protection in Europe.
It rightly focuses on online purchases, which may in 20 years' time represent 25 per cent of all trade in Europe, which is quite considerable.
These vessels will be cross-border in particular.
They will allow consumers to broaden their choice and also to pay much less.
This is real progress.
For SMEs, for all artisans, it is also a very important opportunity to broaden their outlets.

Among the main advances, I would just like to mention two: the retraction deadline of 14 days, the recapitulation of all the information and the overall price to be paid before pressing the last button that passes the order.

And finally, I am proud, in the context of these explanations of vote, to say that I, but all our colleagues, voted unanimously for the political groups, because on such a subject it is not the polemic that we needed, but, of course, the consensus.
That's what we got.

Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would first of all like to welcome the efforts of our colleague, Mr Carlos Coelho, on this very difficult dossier, which required a great deal of technicality, a great deal of work and knowledge of the subject.
The control of our common territory and our European borders is one of the most important challenges we must face, and the technological tool is more than ever at the service of this challenge.
In fact, in the last few years we have seen an unprecedented development of European databases and the exchange of personal data.
What some call a digital tsunami should certainly be confirmed in the years to come.
The SIS, the VIS and the EURODAC are all essential instruments today to ensure the security of our European citizens.
Ensuring the proper operational management of these databases is therefore a major issue to which it is our responsibility to provide an effective response.

This answer is, of course, very delicate and Carlos Cuello has had to face many legal, institutional, budgetary, political and technical obstacles and has nevertheless managed to reach a balanced text which satisfies all stakeholders.
The creation of this network agency seems to be the best solution to ensure the internal security of the Member States.
No other existing institution or agency could now take charge of the proper management of these information systems.
It will improve the management of existing information systems, provide better synergy between these databases and also integrate the instruments that will be adopted in the future.
One of the very delicate questions that arose on this matter was the headquarters of the Agency, where it should be established.
Estonia and France are the only two countries that have applied to host it.
France already hosts the Schengen Information System in Strasbourg, which it has been managing and administering since 1995, and therefore has full technical control of it.
Following the conclusions of the European Council in December 2003, which gave priority to the new Member States, Estonia also wanted to receive the seat of this future agency.

Madam President, it seems to me that the compromise reached is very good. A sort of distribution of the tasks, I conclude, Madam President, has been carried out by transferring the headquarters of the Agency to Tallinn, where the tasks of governance, strategy and programme design will be carried out.
The development and operation of the systems will take place in Strasbourg.
The cost-effectiveness ratio is very balanced and this compromise solution does not call into question the centralised management of IT systems.
Mr President, the transversal social clause and Article 14 of the Treaty of Lisbon bindingly guarantee social rights, in particular the right to access to services of general interest.
It is time to prove to the citizens of Europe that social Europe is on the move.

Our social acquis must therefore be given the full place it deserves in Community law, recognising the specificity of the SSG in terms of competition rules, knowing that these services have a strong local anchor and rely on actors in the social economy.

Mr De Rossa's report is an opportunity to affirm the simple but strong and weighty principles of equality, universality and access to these services, which are collectively organised and are factors of well-being and social progress.
Commissioner, you said it was time to get down to business.
Yes, it is time to get down to business, so I propose that in this debate we actually support a European legislative instrument for social public services.
I therefore invite you to vote on the alternative resolution tabled by the Green Group.
Mr President, the debates on GMOs must necessarily be based on irrefutable arguments, both scientifically and legally.
Legally, there was a need for as varied as solid arguments for Member States wishing to restrict or prohibit GMOs on their territory.
The rapporteur has widened the range of soft marking.
I'm not going to do it.
The scientific basis of this inquiry must also be irrefutable.
The Council has repeatedly called into question the EFSA's scientific assessments, which are also always positive with regard to GMOs, as opposed to national scientific assessments.

In order to restore confidence, shouldn't the existing legislation, which aims to provide a number of scientific guarantees, particularly in terms of long-term impact assessments, be applied beforehand, Commissioner?
Why did the Council's recommendations of October 2008 remain a dead letter?
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, first of all I would like to thank our colleague Simon Busuttil for the tremendous work he has done.
These reflections have enriched the initial proposal and we can only congratulate him on it.
This report outlines a multiplying agency, more suited to the tasks assigned to it.
Recent events have shown us the need for closer cooperation between the European Union, the Member States and the support of a strong agency.
Frontex finally has the means to fulfil its missions.
By being able to acquire or rent its own equipment and by benefiting from the services of its own border guards, it becomes more independent and very efficient.
It is also given new tasks, such as the organisation of voluntary returns or the processing of personal data, so that we can fight cross-border crime while protecting fundamental rights.

This extension of Frontex's competence gives us the means to consider and deal with migration issues through a comprehensive approach and not to confine ourselves to a simple mechanical management of borders.
I approve of the possibility of exchanging personal data with other European agencies, including Europol.
Finally, the human dimension has taken its place in this report.
A strong recognition of human rights is guaranteed by the proposal to set up an advisory council within the Agency.

I can only welcome this comprehensive proposal, which takes a step forward towards the sound and responsible management of our external borders in a context where migration pressures are particularly strong and continuous.

Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Meyer, and my colleagues, who are sometimes critical, but this 2010 activity report is finally a great opportunity to talk about the Committee on Petitions, because it remains too unknown.
Yet it is the Commission, with a direct link, sometimes physical, with the citizen, that can itself attend our debates.
It has an undeniable legitimacy in Parliament and a very long experience thanks to its direct relationship with the citizen.
Indeed, any petitioner can go to Parliament and defend his rights before the Committee on Petitions.
The serenity of the debates, despite the painful cases that are often dealt with, can also be welcomed.
This Commission represents Europe as it should be, listening to the problems of its citizens and working together to find solutions and protect them.
Unfortunately, the means of action and the means of weighing are still limited, particularly with regard to the environmental risk of projects that are sometimes almost completed.
But I also see this when it comes to defending specific cases, such as family rights or the rights of the child in the event of divorce.
We are going to have a mission in November on this subject.
I also regret that the national authorities are not always in a hurry to provide us with all the necessary information.
I would like to thank the European Commission for the research and verification work it is doing, even if sometimes it could go further in the search for the truth.
I must also welcome the constructive work we are doing with the European Ombudsman.
Finally, I call on the citizens to continue to appeal to us through petitions as directly elected representatives.
Our role will always be to safeguard your interests in strict compliance with European law.
Madam President, Commissioner, I welcome this resolution on the lack of a framework because it is our responsibility to recall the extreme urgency of this.
Let us first note that what was a priority yesterday remains even more pressing today.

The absence of reliable definitions and statistical indicators on the unemployment rate cannot prevent us from concluding that the crisis is helping the number of people living below the poverty line to increase from 79 million in 2009 to 84 million, an estimated figure for 2011.
Ladies and gentlemen, three years ago our Parliament, concerned about eradicating poverty, asked the Member States to put an end to the problem of STFs by 2015.
Today, we are even somewhat closer to our goal.
Has the 2010 year, dedicated to the fight against poverty, really been used by the Member States to tackle this great precariousness, the urgency of which has become permanent?
I can only truly doubt it, and I deeply regret it.

In conclusion, I would like to emphasize the need to develop a comprehensive, multi-sectoral strategy for homelessness, because of course there is poverty and the absence of housing, but there are also family problems, health issues, various disabilities and personal vulnerabilities.
We need a comprehensive, effective, ambitious but proportionate approach that takes into account the heterogeneity of individuals, their paths and their breakdown of life.
This is a right, at least a fundamental one, from which a large number of precarious people are deprived.
Madam President, in recent years, as everyone has said, the European Union has been hit by unprecedented disasters, and the ones mentioned here would take all the time of the debate.
I will still quote the Azed F explosion, whose tenth anniversary we commemorated less than a week ago in Toulouse.
A stronger response at European level, as proposed in Mrs Gardini's report, represents a real opportunity to show solidarity between our peoples.

For several years now, the Union has been trying to make this mutual effort operational, and it is now time to act together and not wait for another disaster to hit our territories to learn the lessons.
Today it is a question of making our material, human and financial capabilities available to everyone in order to prevent new tragedies from occurring.
Commissioner, earlier you said that the risks had to be anticipated.

And it is really regrettable that, in this context, the European Commission is considering withdrawing from funding the GMES satellite observation programme, which is recognised by all as an essential instrument for the prevention and coordination of disaster response.
I urge the Commission to reconsider this position and to support these flagship programmes which give Europe an undeniable added value.
I would like to thank Mrs Gardini for her very good report.
I hope that we will adopt it, and it will open the way to European solidarity in the service of the citizen.
Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, the number of poor and unemployed people in the European Union continues to increase.
More than 43 million Europeans are threatened by food poverty.
The hour is serious.
Today, six Member States want to end the food aid programme without any replacement solutions: Germany, Sweden, Denmark, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands and the Czech Republic.
Of course, there is a decision of the Court of Justice and we must respect it.
However, Commissioner, Parliament called you in last July on the initiative of our group, the Greens, and you made relevant proposals to safeguard the programme.
The Greens are ready to work with you on long-term solutions, but once millions of people are dependent on this system, we cannot let the food aid budget be divided by four.
The emergency is real.
If nothing is done by the end of the year, more than 300 million euros will be lacking in the food bank and there is no guarantee that national governments will be able to take over to fill this gap.
So it is a real question of solidarity between peoples.
Let us not let an irresponsible minority of governments deprive millions of Europeans of food aid, because it is first and foremost a matter of survival.
The fight against poverty and malnutrition also requires a reform of the CAP.
We must fundamentally change the way we produce in order to bring food production closer to the people, especially the poorest, who also have the right to healthy and balanced food.
Only a truly sustainable CAP will enable us to ensure that fewer Europeans will need food aid.
The Council must come to its senses and allow those in need to resort to this vital aid.
I am addressing in particular the future Danish government, which will be responsible for ensuring the presidency of the European Union as early as January.
Let's get back to the point, do we need hunger riots in Europe to realize the imperative need to change the logic?
When it comes to saving the banks, the Council has found the solutions, but when it comes to saving the food banks, there is no one left.
It is high time to reaffirm this.
In any case, we will be very vigilant and will not fail to renew our call in a constructive way.
Six Member States are holding the fate of 18 million Europeans in need in their hands.
Six Member States claim to do nothing more or less than legality.
Jurisprudence is one thing, humanism and political choices are another.
How can we not show our anger at those who remain deaf to the cries of alarm from the associations that help the most deprived?

And do we, Members of the European Parliament, representatives of all citizens, want a Europe in which national selfishness sets the policies, with little regard for the citizens of countries in budgetary difficulties?
There is no question of renationalizing this aid.

No, let us maintain this programme, let us give it a stronger legal basis, but let us not let down those who, in the immediate future, in 2012, rely on this aid in times of particularly difficult crises.

Mr President, Commissioner, I will not go back on the cynicism with which the ArcelorMittal group announced the closure of some of its tools in Europe, and in particular in Belgium, in Li√®ge, eventually causing hundreds of direct dismissals and endangering several thousand indirect jobs.
As a Li√®ge resident, I share the astonishment and dismay of the 581 workers who have been laid off from their families.
But I am also thinking of the severe restructuring announced by the steel group in France, Germany and Luxembourg.
The reasons cited are always the same: the poor prospects for the development of the steel market in Europe, the fierce competition with imports from China, Korea and the United States.
Russia and Brazil, the reduction of the car market and, finally, the competitiveness gap, for example, of the Li√®ge site compared to the best factories in Northern Europe.
In addition, and despite a difficult 2010 year, the financial centre of the Belgian steel group Arcelor Mittal has generated a profit of EUR 1 billion.
He spent zero euros in taxes, or a tax rate of zero.
It's particularly shocking.
Group management is mainly financial, with a stop and go policy being implemented on several sites.
And the closure of sites is nothing more in the minds of these leaders than a variable of economic adjustment where human issues are of little importance.
It is no longer acceptable.
You spoke, Commissioner, about the rules.
Is it not time for the Commission to draw up a code of social responsibility which is binding on multinational companies?

It has been six years since our Parliament adopted a report on relocations, the Code of Conduct for Companies, the reimbursement of subsidies and the compulsory consultation between companies, trade unions and public authorities.
Since then, however, it has been difficult to see that these various proposals have been put into practice in any concrete way.
So what is the Commission going to do about it and in what time?
If we are to support the competitiveness of enterprises and make Europe attractive in terms of economic investment, we must also adopt a legislative framework.
A strong European Union to deal with relocations and restructurings and to ensure full consideration of another capital, human capital.
Finally, as far as the Li√®ge site is concerned, I hope that it will be able to benefit from the intervention of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund in order to compensate the unemployed workers.

Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the wave of redundancies affecting workers across Europe should make us think about the role that we, as political leaders, have to play in dealing with multinational companies that are acting in the interests of their workers.

without any social ethics, which operate stock market layoffs and relocations to reduce costs, increase shareholder profits, please rating agencies, despite the disregard for social and environmental standards.

In its resolution of 20 September on the future of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, Parliament clearly expressed its willingness to support, above all, employees affected by the negative effects of restructuring.
But we have also asked the Commission to ensure consistency between the EMFF interventions and the industrial policy of the European Union, in particular through the use of the Structural Funds.

We have also insisted that the future EMFF regulation be improved in such a way that the Fund does not produce what it produces today on multinational companies, the moral and random effects, as is the case with ArcelorMittal and Nokia.
Commissioner, we can no longer look separately at the question of the Structural Funds and the Globalisation Adjustment Fund without

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission's proposal for a directive on the protection of workers from the risks related to exposure to carcinogens and mutagens has been rejected by the Council.
Mr President, the European Ombudsman is conducting a thorough investigation into complaints against the institutions and bodies of the European Union.

This instrument is both necessary to facilitate the free movement of our businesses and citizens, but it is also a formidable guarantee, especially in the face of the Union's critics, who too often say that the European Union is just a bureaucratic machine without control.
It is clearly nonsense that Europe is doing a real job on itself, thanks in particular to the European Mediator.
But let me make a point which I very much regret, in which the Commission is under fire from criticism.
First of all, there are the figures 65 and the real figure and not 12 of the investigations opened by the Ombudsman concerning the European Commission.

There are also actors, many companies come to us to explain their misunderstanding to the Commission, to a European Commission which remains deaf to their demands, in particular for access to documents, as well as to the question of transparency in decision-making.
Few people find themselves there.

And finally, there is, from personal experience, I must confess to you, that I have sometimes been shocked by the reactions of certain services of the European Commission present in the Committee on Petitions.
As you know, the European Commission gives us its position on petitions, a position which we always take into account and which is necessary.

But it is sometimes the case that representatives of the European Commission refuse to answer the questions of a Member of Parliament or take refuge behind a tongue of wood, almost as well as politicians and citizens who are pleading their case.

I would therefore like to remind you that Europe must have a human face, that behind the administrative problems raised and solved by the Ombudsman there are Europeans who are relieved to be listened to but disappointed by the

This behaviour of citizens was then negatively marked by their confrontation with the institutions, perhaps creating a feeling of revolt, of incomprehension and, in the end, perhaps of Euroscepticism.
I sincerely hope that these criticisms and those of the Ombudsman against the institutions in general will be heard.
Madam President, professional mobility and growth, professional mobility and competitiveness in our European Union are the terms in which the subject of the day is raised.
We, the EPP Group, have given our support to the report by our colleague, Mrs McLaren King, to the preparation of which we have made a great contribution and which we of course support.

The main recommendations of this report are for more professional mobility, more simplification and efficiency in the procedures for the recognition of professional qualifications, while guaranteeing the safety of patients and consumers.
But it is in terms of the path to growth that the challenge of increasing professional mobility arises.
Moreover, the Forum for a Single Market, which was held in Krakow at the beginning of October, was not wrong.

This reminded Member States that they had to recognise the potential of the internal market to boost growth and job creation and that they had to act to remove all obstacles to the completion of the internal market.
The European Council of 23 October also set as one of the key priorities the achievement of smart, sustainable growth.
This includes the implementation of the twelve priority proposals of the Single Market Act, the twelve proposals made by the Commission, on the recognition of professional qualifications.

We see clearly that it is by increasing professional mobility that we can hope to unleash the growth potential of the internal market, our internal market of 500 million inhabitants, 500 million consumers.

Professional mobility must therefore not only make it possible, if we strengthen it, if we modernise it, if we improve the free movement of our compatriots within this market, but also, we hope, to make it possible to acquire additional growth margins.
That is why we have, in particular, I would like to emphasize a practical recommendation, namely that we in the EPP should support the setting up of a voluntary voluntary cooperative.
Madam President, I would first of all like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Casmarek, on his excellent work.
I would like to say that it is important that every year the European Parliament draws up a report on the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, as far as possible.
This Assembly plays a decisive role in strengthening the North-South dialogue and in establishing a development policy based on partnership and exchange.
The year 2010 was a rich year for the PPE, which met twice, as its predecessors said, in Spain and in the RDC, in order to exchange views, in particular.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the impact of climate change in the ACP countries, the impact of the global crisis, or the freedom and independence of the media and food security.
But in 2010, the PPE also sent its first observation mission to the elections of this legislature.
I had the honour of co-chairing this mission in Burundi for the presidential elections with my colleague Asharid, a Member of Parliament from Mali.
This election observation mission was a real success.

We have been able to meet all the political actors concerned and, thanks to the dual origin of this delegation, which is both ACP and European, we have embodied a different legitimacy from the European or African missions.
I therefore invite the EPP Bureau to renew this experience, which makes it possible to put into practice the solidarity and privileged relations which unite the European Union with the ACP countries.
I would like to thank Mr Dardenne for his report.
The crisis is certainly economic and financial, but it is above all a social crisis for our fellow citizens.
Reducing the number of people in precarious situations by 20 million by 2020 requires strong measures involving the different levels of public power.

We must more than ever keep the commitments made by the European Union in 2010 during the European Year of Combating Poverty and Social Exclusion and during the creation of the European Platform against Poverty and Social Exclusion to have a European framework for social and territorial cohesion.

We need to sustain and optimise European funds, in particular the programme of aid to the most deprived for the time being, improve social protection, support local or national initiatives that develop services for the reception of children, the elderly and dependent persons.
Poverty is a scourge to be fought horizontally and it is now time to act to enable the most deprived to get out of their poverty.

And we must, as political leaders at European, national and local level, take the necessary measures to ensure that they have unimpeded access to housing, health care, justice, education and a first job with a minimum income, perhaps indexed according to the poverty level of each Member State.
Investing in the promotion of innovation and social experimentation and in the reduction of poverty will enable us to put in place a sustainable, intelligent and inclusive growth strategy.
The Europe we want and need today is a Europe of solidarity.
Mr President, I would first of all like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Leving, on her excellent work.

As rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Development, I am pleased that the Committee on Fisheries has taken up the elements contained in our opinion, because it is crucial that the development dimension
be taken into account in measures to combat illegal fishing worldwide, in the name of policy coherence and close links with development policy.
Indeed, the fight against illegal fishing requires comprehensive solutions and the involvement of all States, including those in development.
However, it is necessary that the technical and financial capabilities of the States are also taken into account in the actions to be taken.
Indeed, the same constraints cannot be imposed on developed or developing countries without accompanying measures.
For example, small island states have very limited capacities.
They must therefore be accompanied in their efforts to combat illegal fishing.
That is why the Union will have to strengthen the financial envelope for the fisheries sector when it concludes agreements in this area in developing countries.

In addition, it is crucial that measures to combat illegal fishing are applied, as this practice undermines the development of countries as it reduces the financial resources that these countries could draw from economic fishing activity.
However, these resources are necessary for developing countries to implement social, economic and educational policies.

Finally, it is important that the European Union, when implementing its measures to combat illegal fishing in developing countries, promotes the involvement of civil society and businesses, alongside the beneficiary States, in aid.
A holistic approach is needed to end this scourge of illegal fishing.
Mr President, I would like to say that, in large part because of these outermost regions, the European Union is the world's leading maritime power.
This is a major asset for Europe, too, and the development and implementation of a major policy on the sea, oceans and seabed is essential for tomorrow.
But I fear that with 20 or 50 million euros, this will not be enough to meet this great challenge.

The fight against illegal fishing is part of this major policy and it is urgent at European level to find an adequate solution to this problem, in particular in the context of international cooperation.
I would also point out that the maritime areas of Guadeloupe, Guyana, Martinique, Mayotte and R√©union are regularly violated and looted.
As the report does not mention it, I take this opportunity to draw the attention of my colleagues and the Commission to this particular problem.
Madam President, I would first of all like to congratulate the Polish Presidency on its dynamism and voluntarism.
Next week, at the Council, our Heads of State and Government will have to take decisions which are essential for the future of the euro area, for the future of the Union.
They will also have to deal seriously with the recovery of growth.

Having said that, we can see that today financial stability has become the priority of the priorities and that the pressures, the tensions that are exerted from outside on the countries of the euro area, but also within the euro area, are ruining our credibility and undermining confidence.
And to hope for the return of confidence, we must restore financial stability, break the terrible progress of national deficits and sovereign debts, and so on.
Financial stability has become the priority of the priorities, it has become a burning obligation for all.
Our democracies have all engaged in very courageous programmes to clean up their public finances, to reduce their debt, but financial stability is also a prerequisite for any recovery in growth.
But whoever says financial stability, budgetary discipline, because it goes hand in hand, of course, must also say solidarity.
It seems important to us to ensure this double movement of financial stability, budgetary discipline and solidarity.
One last word on democracy.
Be careful not to irresponsibly disqualify our democratic institutions.

Rather than considering resorting to a jurisdictional mechanism, I would say to sanction in the event of budgetary deviations, let us consider rather mechanisms of control and sanction exercised by democratic institutions.

To be perfectly frank, I am not the spokesman for the French Foreign Minister and, very frankly, even though I belong to the same political group as him, I am not in a position to communicate the statements of the French Foreign Minister on a regular basis.
To be perfectly frank, I am not aware of any recent statements by Alain Jupp√© in this regard.
I simply think that France's current position is to reaffirm constantly that the euro is truly at the heart of our European construction, that the safeguarding of the euro, that

I would like to say that the safeguarding of this common project is the safeguarding of the European Union, and in this movement to safeguard the euro we must, of course, think about the future, think about protecting the younger generations and preserving peace on our continent.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow we will vote for the third time on the new instrument for cooperation with the countries of the Mediterranean.
The development programme provides for accompanying measures in the banana sector for ACP banana exporting countries following the reduction of their tariff preferences, the BAM.
This aid programme has a budget of EUR 190 million and targets 10 ACP countries by 2013.
It is of crucial importance to our African and Caribbean partners, as the banana sector has considerable economic and social weight in these countries.
If all of Parliament's demands on the application of delegated acts have not been taken up for this instrument, I very much regret it.
Nevertheless, we have succeeded in making progress.
The text provides for clear objectives and precise criteria for the allocation of resources to the Commission.
The Commission also made a statement specifying the methodology used.

In addition, we have a Council statement on the next multiannual financial framework, which states that the latter would duly take account of delegated acts in the instruments for foreign aid after 2013.
Finally, in its resolution, Parliament states, and this seems to me to be a major point, that this is by no means a precedent.

And I would like to tell you that I am returning from Togo, where the 22nd session of the ACP-EU ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP ACP
The funds should have been unblocked two years ago.
We must be aware of the deplorable consequences for our ACP partners if the BAM ICD is rejected.
The situation of some farmers is dramatic, we can no longer wait and we must act accordingly.
I therefore count on you to support the text.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, our coordinator, Mr Tissbergmann, cannot be here tonight for personal reasons.
However, I know that he fully shares my analysis on this matter.
The conciliation on this legislative package has been long and tedious and, if the result on the human rights instruments and the ICI Plus is satisfactory, we are very far from the banana instrument.

Thus, the compromise reached on this text reverses the mandate given to our negotiating team, which was to place Parliament on the same level as the Council in all programming decisions on the choice of strategic priorities and financial allocations.
Because these are powers of our Assembly and of the very spirit of the Treaty of Lisbon, which is discussed here.
The choice of programming priorities is a highly political decision on which our Assembly must have its say.
By categorically refusing to recognise any power of control in Parliament and by using shameful blackmail, the Council has once again shown a reprehensible ideological retreat.
But the Member States must understand that the European Union's external action is now a shared competence between our institutions.
That is why our Parliament must remain sovereign and reject the proposal on the banana instrument.
This is the only way we can show the Council and the Commission that Parliament wants more transparency in Community decisions.
If we lose this battle, the absurdity would be that we should wait for a new treaty to finally obtain the powers already provided for by the Lisbon Treaty.
Mr President, at the risk of shocking the most federalist of you, I think that a defence policy is an eminently national policy.
It meets the strategic, diplomatic and security needs of each nation.
The sharing of capabilities is nothing more than a deprivation of sovereignty, and the single market for military equipment is a big joke when some Member States believe that
The defence of Washington is guaranteed, it is equipped primarily with American equipment, Europe being unable, in this area as in so many others, to impose the Community preference.
With regard to the common security challenges of the Member States of the Union, there is nothing that cannot be resolved by intergovernmental cooperation, apart from any intervention by Brussels.

I am sorry, but to entrust these areas to Mrs Ashton would be to recognise that Moody's and Standard & Poor's have a legitimacy to judge our economic policies, to accept that the Mercosur couple could impose on 27 peoples a German Europe, pure mental aberration.

For thirty years, and even more since the disappearance of the Soviet threat, defence budgets have been the first to be sacrificed on the altar of budgetary rigor, to the point of rendering most of our military tools useless.

They are deficient or outdated, and this for purely financial reasons, each expecting from his neighbour or the supposed big American brother the efforts he is no longer willing to consent to himself.
But you're wrong.

It is only by returning to independent and resolute national policies that we will be able to provide each of us with the means necessary not only for our national security and interests, but also for the cooperation of these means to meet common challenges.
Adding weakness and gaps has never made a force.

Mr President, I wanted to support the French delegation of the EPP Group to the Treaty on European Stability, Coordination and Economic Governance and its support for the main conclusions reached by the Council.
Let's not get confused.
This Treaty represents an important step towards greater economic and budgetary integration and financial stability.
Let's say it again here.
There can be no sustainable recovery of growth and employment without a clean-up of our public finances.
Of course, growth is not decreed, it is not a treaty that can revive growth on its own.
But a treaty, that is to say a set of rules and mutual commitments, can bring confidence and accountability.

And as the President of the Socialist Group thought it was good to introduce political policy in this House, and by alluding to the upcoming French presidential campaign, referring to the Socialist candidate in this French presidential election, I wanted to respond.
We, the EPP, consider the statements of the French Socialist candidate, who has declared that he wants to renegotiate the Treaty concluded by 25 May, to be totally irresponsible.
We negotiate what and with whom.
These words are totally irresponsible.
They make little of the French State's word, of the French State's commitment.

Madam President, Madam Ashton, Madagascar is one of the poorest countries in the world, and is experiencing a political crisis whose outcome will be the application of the road map to presidential and legislative elections.
The growth of this country is negative.
In normal times, our contribution is close to 50 of the country's budget.
The European Union has rightly suspended its budgetary support for the ninth and tenth EDFs, but not for the MDGs.
During this time, the population suffers and the companies based in Madagascar are sometimes contributed in spite of them.

While supporting your position, we would like you to weigh with all your might with the SADC so that the legal and judicial impasse over the return of the former President can be resolved as soon as possible, as one of the most sensitive elements of the application of this roadmap.

I would like to know your opinion on the subject and I would also like to inform you that the European Union-Madagascar Friendship Group, which we have just set up in the European Parliament, is available to work with you and the Commission in the interest of the Malagasy people and in the defence of the values of our Union.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to commend the rapporteur, Mr Iturguy, for the quality of his work, for the long negotiating work he had to undertake and for the patience he was able to show.

We are finally voting on this report, which is extremely important because it allows us to bring up in this House, before the Commission and the Council, the difficulties and fears of our fellow citizens.
Here is further evidence, if any, of the effectiveness of the right of petition in Europe.
Environmental petitions are the majority and waste is a major concern of our fellow citizens.
This subject must answer a social problem.
We consume at Tuva.
We are only now realizing that what we do not consume, we throw away.
This awareness must be absolutely strengthened among the citizens, that is clear.
But this report is also a reminder to the Member States.
It is nevertheless worrying to see that the States do not seem to be in control of the situation.
Only six Member States transposed the waste directive, the waste framework directive, in time.
The number of complaints received on this subject sometimes demonstrates the lack of transparency in the choice of discharge locations.
Finally, and this is the most worrying, organized crime seems to be doing what it wants.
A market of 75 billion euros is bound to attract the greedy.
The states must send a strong signal.
We need to increase sanctions against companies that divert public contracts to get rich.
This report is a warning to the Member States, but the European Commission must also play its part and check the proper application of the waste directives.
We need to make this case visible, but also credible.
If no one plays the game, we will continue to waste time and money on verification and counter-verify procedures that may take years.
Let's listen to the petitioners' message and stop this mess as soon as possible.
Commissioner, Mr Rapporteur, I would first of all like to congratulate Mr Nicholson on the courage he has shown to the Council and the Commission.
Nevertheless, I fear that what we have achieved will not allow for a balance between producers and industrialists.
This agreement reminds me of the illusion that children tell us about, of a paradise where vegetarian lions would eat grass alongside sheep.
I don't believe it for a second. Since 2003, Mrs Fischer Boel has done everything in her power to ideologically destroy dairy farms.
In October 2009, the Court of Auditors nevertheless recognised the effectiveness of these milk quotas.

But today we are in a situation that is going to be even more dramatic and we see what is happening now in Denmark, where the most solid farms, with the increase in production, are all in bankruptcy, with land prices falling by 40%.
Do we want this at European level?
I say no, we must control production with the participation of the public authorities.
Madam President, Commissioner, the standards for the protection of personal data in third countries are still considerably different from European standards.
However, it is our duty to ensure that our European minimum standards of protection, which we have, are respected and guaranteed to European citizens.
It is essential that personal data be treated fairly and collected for specific and legitimate purposes.

European citizens must be able to guarantee themselves the right of access and rectification of the personal data of those concerned and to lodge a judicial appeal in the event of a violation of their rights.
Action is needed to enable European and international standards to coexist and to resolve a legal conflict that could be harmful to European citizens.
European legislation alone is not enough.
It must articulate itself and coexist intelligently with international standards, because we cannot get rid of our duties and commitments to European citizens.
This situation echoes other debates within this Chamber.
It reminds us of the relevance of projects such as the establishment of a European programme for the monitoring of terrorist financing.

Such a system would allow us to have a tool that has demonstrated its effectiveness in the United States, while fully respecting internal law and therefore the protection of the personal data of European citizens.
The European institutions must continue their commitment in this direction and fully assume their standards of protection.
Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteurs for their work.

In response to the crisis, the European Union has just spent more than a year strengthening its economic governance to avoid macroeconomic imbalances and budgetary deficits that are too large and threaten the European economy, but this has not prevented social exclusion or the increase in unemployment.
It is time, no, it is now urgent, that the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy should be an absolute priority for the European Commission and for the Member States in a perspective of growth.

Each State will have to put in place a national employment plan, which means that the emphasis should be on such subjects as mixing, training, reconversion, microcredit, apprenticeship, paid internships, etc.
However, as Commissioner Andor pointed out earlier, we have 23 million unemployed in Europe, but also 23 million SMEs and 23 billion of European funds devoted to employment and non-use.
We could almost make it a 23 strategy.
And that's not counting the 60 billion euros of untouched cohesion funds.
In Denmark and the Netherlands, social initiatives have been taken and their effectiveness has been proven, based on flexicurity.
Let's get inspired by that.

This also means that our social policy as a whole must be more adapted, with more favourable social incentives than those linked to unemployment and active support for all socially virtuous enterprises.
We had poverty reduction targets to be achieved by 2020, but we already know that they will not be achieved without strong and adequate measures taken by the Member States.

Our role as parliamentarians must therefore be fully exercised and it is our responsibility to demand that the same energy devoted to taking strong economic governance measures also be devoted to ambitious, effective and binding social governance measures.
Madam President, there is no doubt that the cause of women owes much to Europe.
The principle of equality between men and women was already enshrined in the Treaty of Rome and has been constantly reaffirmed in many treaties since then.
Equality between men and women is really a fundamental value of our European project.
In this respect, Europe has always worked very voluntarily for gender equality, for the cause of the promotion of women.
Little by little, progress has been made.
Many legislative instruments have been adopted, directives have been put in place.
There has been a very active and vigilant Commission on women's rights and gender equality in our Parliament for many years.
A European Institute for Gender Equality has been set up.
Programs are put in place, financial means are voted on year after year.
More recently, on 2 March, we had the opportunity to celebrate, for the second time, the European Day for Equal Treatment and Equal Pay.
There is no doubt that the legislative arsenal exists, the European will has been put into practice on several occasions.
But it is important to note that the fight for equality between men and women, and in particular for wage equality, is still relevant.
There is still, on average, a wage gap of around
Women still earn 17 less than men in equal work.
This is, of course, completely unacceptable.
Parliament's Committee on Women is currently working on a draft resolution calling on the European Commission to revise the 2006 Equality Directive.
This is one of the most worrying and heartbreaking battles of the concerns and demands of European women in all our societies.

On another subject, the introduction of quotas, quotas both in the decision-making bodies of large companies and in political life, I come from a country, France, which adopted a long time ago, already a long time ago.
Ten years of binding rules on quotas in political life and, more recently, about a year ago, a law on the introduction of quotas in the boards of directors of large companies.
France is not the only country, of course, to have opted for such legislation.
So what is the balance after a few years of application in one case, a few months in the other, forced to find that things have moved, that things have progressed?
So a necessary evil.
Quotas have an effect.

So, Commissioner, you have recently taken an important step towards the introduction of quotas at European level in the decision-making bodies of large companies by launching this large public consultation to gather opinions on the actions to be taken, the possible legislative actions to be taken.
On this subject, you will have my full support.
Mr President, Commissioner, on the occasion of this resolution, allow me to address two subjects first of all the issue of water management in the world and in Europe.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has already made a number of proposals to the Council and the European Parliament on this subject.
The stakes, as we know, are high and the big deal of the 21st century.
It is because we will have answers that we will have peace in the world and in Europe.
We know the stakes, we know the stakes in management, we know the stakes in food security.

And on the occasion of this forum, which, as our colleague Mr Rivazzi has pointed out, is too much of a purely commercial concern, the discussion which has been taking place in Marseille in recent days is at the heart of it.
One question is why there is no coherence between water management and water-related resources and the common agricultural policy, because
Nothing in the CAP reform is indicated with regard to this management, as our colleague Mr Sarbout said earlier.
So give us some answers.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would first of all like to thank the rapporteur and our assistants for their work.
This report now bears his name very well, namely to remove obstacles to citizenship.
Europe is a formidable project, but it is too often pointed out that it is not yet perfectly defined.
Take, for example, the economic crisis.
It has highlighted our weaknesses and enabled us to build stronger regulatory institutions for our single market.
For the European citizen, it is the same.
The Committee on Petitions, the real Office of Complaints, records every day the grievances of our fellow citizens.
In three days' time, the European Citizens' Initiative will complete this system.
Despite all our policies calling for mobility, membership, European values and trade, there are still far too many obstacles to the exercise of citizenship.
A citizen who does not feel European is a citizen who will not go to the polls, a citizen who will not see the interest that Europe represents in his daily life.
With my colleagues from the EPP, we have made a lot of proposals, most of them, and I would like to thank them for that.
It is a report which must produce a sense of belonging and European identity which we must recreate and maintain through these measures.
Our Europe must be a Europe that protects.
Commissioner Viviane Reding has made 25 very concrete proposals in favour of citizens.
They are essential to restoring trust between the citizen and Europe.
But the proposals contained in this report reflect other expectations of our fellow citizens: online shopping, relocation, children's rights, employment.
We are still struggling to take full advantage of the opportunities offered by Europe.
Rights are exercised, claims are heard.
We are the relays here.
The European Year of Citizenship in 2013 will have to demonstrate to citizens that, along with free movement, there is also free use of rights in Europe.
Madam President, I believe that taxation is an interesting tool for changing behaviour.

Mr President, I believe that energy consumption must be accompanied by an indicative price signal for the consumer and, above all, I believe that in order to avoid any distortion in the internal market, we must try to bring our tax practices closer together.
The principle of proportionality between the different levels of taxation of energy products therefore seems to me to be a necessity.
In the case before us, for example, this would put an end to the diesel tourism that we are currently witnessing, which is not acceptable.
I therefore share the philosophy of the Commission's proposal to revise the directive.

However, if we are to achieve our objectives in terms of reducing CO2 emissions or energy efficiency, our collective decisions must not punish citizens or sectors particularly exposed to CO2 emissions.

The volatility of prices on world markets and I am thinking of the agricultural sector, for example, the proposal for a directive will have an impact, although differentiated according to the level of taxation in each Member State, but an impact on the price of diesel.
The question is who will ultimately have to bear this price increase.
Are there any real, practical, realistic, consumer-friendly alternatives?
As a fictitious rapporteur on the Committee on the Environment, I support an ambitious but above all sustainable position for all.

I therefore call for greater progressiveness and the entry into force of the proposal and its principle of proportionality by 2030, through a new impact assessment, updating the one on which the Commission is based, which was nevertheless carried out five years ago.

A month ago, here in Europe, we had a debate on the wave of redundancies in Europe as a result of the economic crisis, in particular at Arcelor, a multinational present in nine European Member States which is restructuring its production tool in Europe in the face of a demand for steel in Bern.
Since the closure of two blast furnaces in Belgium and Luxembourg and the closure of one in France, it is estimated that by 2012 nearly 6 direct jobs will be threatened.
Beyond unacceptable practices such as stop and go, which should be better managed, there is the more global issue of European steel and adaptation to change, which awaits extremely urgent answers.

Six months ago, the Commission announced the need to conduct, in the light of the economic crisis, a new consultation exercise on responsible management of restructuring with the social partners and public authorities.
My question is simple, six months later, where are we?
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would first of all like to reverse the unfounded allegations of 500 to 1 million fake biometric passports circulating in France.
France takes the risks of fraud involving identity cards very seriously.
It does not take offenses in this area lightly.
At the initiative of his government, the usurpation of identity is a crime punishable by one year in prison and a fine of 15 euros.
The conditions for the issuing of identity cards have been simplified, which has enabled the prefectures to find additional means to combat this fraud.
Thus, a fraud reference is designated in each prefecture.
In addition, the provisions on the security of identity documents have been strengthened.
For example, the civil status data provided will be verified between administrative services as much as possible by means of dematerialisation in order to limit the risks of falsification.
Some birth certificates are also issued on secured paper.
The same rigorousness applies to the justification trap of two missiles.
The Ministry of the Interior has committed itself to increasing the security of home justifications by introducing a barcode.

The classic treatment of a title application includes the authorised consultation of the useful files, the comparison of all the shares produced in previous title applications, the possible authentication of the supporting shares.

The security of the issuance of securities is also guaranteed by the double appearance of the applicant at the time of the submission of the application and then the withdrawal of the title and the withdrawal of two digital fingerprints.
Not to mention the enhanced checks for the renewal of lost and stolen securities for comparative purposes with the data stored by the prefectures, I conclude.
In addition, France is reporting to the international cooperation bodies, in particular to Interpol.
Ladies and gentlemen, France, like the rest of the European Union, is committed.
Mr President, Commissioner, first of all, our fellow citizens are increasingly looking for and consuming locally produced and seasonal food for health and quality reasons.
We must find ways of enabling farmers to respond effectively and quickly to this growing demand.

We must support the establishment of local infrastructure for producers, such as the maintenance of nearby slaughterhouses, which, while guaranteeing strict health control, make it possible to develop local short circuits and strengthen direct sales.
Support for local agriculture and direct sales should help producers to market their products and make them known to consumers.
The strengthening of these direct relations will enable farmers to retain a larger share of the added value created by their farms.

Direct sales within the farm must be promoted and facilitated and collective actions by farmers who wish to open collective outlets that can offer local consumers a wider range of products must be supported.

The European Commission must facilitate the emergence, sustainability and development of direct sales systems for consumer deliveries, such as the Amap in France, which allow nearly 3 farmers to supply 60 families.

Finally, Member States must be able to add other criteria, in particular the size of the farm, the volume of production or the traditional nature of the product, in order to define proximity agriculture.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I welcome the fact that this amending budget on the financing of ITER, which was voted on, won a large majority in the Committee on Budgets on 29 March.
By financing this surplus, we are avoiding throwing away a strategic project of fundamental research in which the European Union plays a leading role and we are honouring our international promises.
It should be recalled that none of the seven partners in the Euratom Community questioned its overall contribution to the project.
Japan, despite the tragedy of Fukushima, has decided to scrupulously comply with its budgetary commitments in ITER.
Without this agreement, hundreds of researchers would have had to suspend their work and the ITER project would have suffered harmful delays.
Today, a thousand people work for ITER in Kadarash.
From 2015 to 2017, the construction phase of the buildings and the assembly of the machine could mobilise up to 4 people on this site.
In conclusion, Mr President, ITER is a pride for Europe and a symbol of our excellence.
Mr President, Commissioner, rapporteur, thank you for the work we have done together.
The European Union needs a manifesto, a common political vision on the major environmental challenges, the 2020 horizon and beyond.
It is therefore all the more useful to launch a seventh action programme for the environment by bringing together the existing financial framework and mobilising new funding resources.
This programme must ensure coherence and articulation between the European Union's environmental strategies and sectoral policies, such as agriculture.
Fisheries, research and innovation, health, transport, regional development, land use planning and urban policies, of course.
Despite the economic crisis that is plaguing the European Union, we must not give in to a short-term vision and abandon all ambition in the environmental and climate field.
Inaction would be fatal.
The stakes are too high, particularly with regard to the efficient use of our resources and the valuation of natural capital.
We must therefore invest decisively in the sustainable economy and eco-innovation, which is a source of growth, competitiveness and jobs.
It is up to us to promote eco-design, recycling, but also environmental labelling of products in order to avoid waste and bad consumption choices.
We cannot put an end to this environmental pedagogy, which is necessary for European citizens.
The environmental action programme is an instrument of political programming, but it is also a tool of communication.
It must provide the necessary readability and predictability for national and local administrations, citizens, but also entrepreneurs and investors on the European Union's environmental choices.
European regulation must not become a punishment or a trap.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the face of the profound changes to which our world is subject today, the EU must reform its system of generalised preferences.
Like any compromise, this one doesn't break the rule.
If it is satisfactory from a strictly commercial point of view, it is far from perfect, because we must bear in mind that this regulation is addressed to developing countries.
By developing its new paradigm of differentiation, the Commission says it wants to refocus its action on the poorest countries.
This does not seem entirely sustainable at first glance.
To this end, however, the Commission has developed a strictly accounting view based on the sole criterion of GDP per capita.
We can see the limit of this approach.
It is a problem in many developing countries with average incomes, whose economies are not very diversified and which are vulnerable to climate change.
The compromise reached with the Council does not answer this question, and that is why I call on my colleagues to vote in favour of the three amendments which will be tabled on this text.
Mr Commissioner, the problem of the availability of public consultations in the various languages of the European Union is unfortunately not new.

This is a crucial question in my view, because I have already asked not only several written questions to the European Commission since 2008, but I have also personally questioned Mr Barroso in writing.

The Commission must comply with the principle of equal access to information for all European citizens, as the Court of First Instance of the European Communities recalled in its judgment of 20 November 2008.
Mr President, I was not at all satisfied with the European Commission's response that public consultations do not claim to provide a fully representative image of all opinions.
According to this answer, the Commission takes account of the fact that certain positions and views may be overrepresented to the detriment of others.
That's not an answer.
I am wondering about the criteria for measuring the overrepresentation of the European population.
If written consultations are not over-representative because of the availability in English alone, for example, they lack the purpose of consulting European citizens.
Thus, the result gives a wrong indication and should not be used by the European Commission.
If we want to keep written consultations as a tool underpinning the European Commission's legislative proposals, we must ensure that they are democratic, transparent and fair to all citizens.

Thus, if the European Commission is to carry out written consultations, it must take its responsibilities and provide the necessary resources for multilingualism and the translation of questionnaires.
In conclusion, I would like to add that multilingualism is not the only obstacle.

It would also be necessary to take account of the too short deadlines for the submission of contributions and the lack of resources available to the Commission to communicate on these consultations, which are unfortunately especially accessible to those who are initiated, and I thank you for that.
The proposed regulations are intended to give the European Commission increased powers to control national budgets and economic policies.
The rules will be stricter and the failing states will be forced by the technocrats in Brussels to cut budgets and carry out structural reforms in order to restore their financial balance.
This enhanced surveillance is called custody.
States will be punished, fines will be imposed, financial sanctions will be tightened and more automatic.
Although some amendments are aimed at preventing budgetary austerity by means of growth measures alone, your proposals are only there to pass the ball.
Growth, you know, like me, it doesn't happen.
Without consulting the peoples and with the complicity of Brussels, we are definitively losing our budgetary sovereignty, our freedom to choose our policies.

And when, little by little, according to the Chinese thief's tactics, the bureaucratic, technocratic and totalitarian state of Europe has finished forming, we will have lost our freedom as a people altogether.
Mr President, without underestimating the importance of the economic choices we have to make, you will allow me to insist on a more political remark in the context of this debate.
In recent weeks we have again seen evidence of the double-talk of some great European leaders or those who believe in themselves as such.
While everyone is constantly advocating for the coordination of economic, budgetary and fiscal policies, finally worthy of the name, this requirement even appears as a condition.
Mr Crouimalin, once you have settled in your home, it is wise to reject the balanced recommendations emanating from the European Parliament.
The Commission must either break free from certain commitments or, in the worst case, raise public opinion against these Brussels ousters, as they say.
This irresponsible attitude could be laughable if we were not in such a tragic situation.
I can tell you quite clearly that our debates on stability, the necessary clean-up of public finances or on the efforts to be made in the field of growth are, of course, devoted to the
It is a failure if the mistakes of the past in terms of debt and public deficit do not end and if the governments of the Member States continue in their deception.
We're playing with fire right now.
European discipline must play a role for all, without exception, even for the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg.
This requires a minimum of courage and our public opinions are prepared to do so, much more than some of their leaders would like to believe.
And one last word to Mrs Goulard, otherwise I have to show her the blue card.

Mr President, I would first of all like to welcome the determination of the European Commission, and in particular of you, Commissioner, to have tirelessly put the revival and deepening of the internal market at the top of the European agenda.

You recall, Commissioner, that for more than two years now both the Commission and the European Parliament have been working to identify the missing links in the internal market, to identify the issues and sectors for which more internal market is needed, more internal market for more growth, more competitiveness, more jobs.

The European Council, for its part, also ended up, later on, by emphasising the importance it attached to the rapid and effective implementation of the twelve priority proposals for the internal market, the twelve levers for growth.
Rather than constantly trying to invent new growth tools, we have every interest in working with the toolbox we already have.

We therefore take the opportunity of the resolution which will be put to the vote in this House tomorrow to send a strong political message to the Member States about the need for more speed and efficiency in the transposition of the directives already adopted.
