I will only mention one of them, namely the strengthening of the mobility of workers, greater ease of movement, greater fluidity of movement.
We will welcome with great interest, Commissioner, the second stage of the Single Market Act which you will present after the summer.
We will be able to show both political voluntarism and the ability to put pressure on the Member States.
We have known the Mediator scandal for some time.
We now have the scandal of breast implants, which unfortunately highlights, as you said, Commissioner, the malfunctioning of European health security.
This scandal of breast implants, these 14 years of scandals, 1996 to 2010 unpunished.
There are 500 prosthetics carried around the world, that's 8 withdrawals of a plant, 48 confirmed cases of cancer.
Finally, 3 complaints have been filed, and this figure is shocking.

How, despite the warnings of the US Food and Drug Administration, Commissioner, and the number of complaints and convictions for prosthetic rupture filed in Britain, in France in particular, have national and European agencies been able to avoid such a scandal?
This tragedy immediately led us to consider improving the European system of medical device control, as you have just explained.
We must, Commissioner, build a new system today that can avoid scandal, but it is a new system that must be built.
It is announced for the autumn, as you indicated, this new legislation.
As co-author of this resolution, I am, of course, satisfied.
But, Commissioner, you seem to want to take account of a large part of our concerns as dictated by this resolution.
So why make an unacceptable exception for a large number of Members here?
Why not want to create a marketing authorisation for the most at risk third-class medical devices?
Commissioner Dalli, can you explain your position to me?
Mr President, we are currently experiencing a situation where production is increasing by more than two and a half per cent, while industrialists are lowering prices.
In Italy, Germany, England and all the European countries, prices are falling.
This means very clearly that prices are linked to production volumes and that production volumes must be organised and prices at the same time.
At the same time, today producers are the victims of an increase of more than 44 percent in plant proteins and 30 percent in the price of cereals.
Parliament has already voted on the need to ensure that surplus value is distributed among producers and that farmers are not victims of enterprises and large-scale distribution.

I ask the Commission today, but also the Council, to come back to the question of production control, but at the same time I say very clearly that the Member States must take care of their own households, because there are countries which have respected the rules on quotas and others which have not.
And that is also what has caused these quotas to be called into question.
So there is a double responsibility, the Commission and the Member States.
Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, a single European railway area is a fine policy of European integration.
This is a good policy where the construction of Europe is at the heart of the daily concerns of Europeans.

It is too often cited because, in the absence of it, Europe is finally showing the way with this directive to a major policy of sustainable transport and opening the way to a major policy of railway investment for employment.

I welcome the main measures taken in the organisation of the railway network, the establishment of national regulators in each Member State and the creation of a multiannual investment contract for five years, thus stipulating the financing commitments of the European Union.
I also welcome the establishment of a financial flow transparency between managers and operators in the framework of integrated enterprises.

Finally, I welcome the confirmation by the European Parliament of certain guarantees, particularly on the social side, such as the absence of a reference to the minimum service and the total disaggregation between the CNR game and the operator.

But let me mention a requirement that the European Commission stops considering the liberalisation of the railway sector as the only strategic horizon for the development of a single railway area and that it decides on a European strategy for integrated investment in favour of employment in Europe.
I would also like to ask you a question, Commissioner Kallas.
Three days after the European Council of 28 and 29 June, after the validation of a growth pact of EUR 120 billion to revive the European economy.
In particular, by investing in infrastructure, can you tell us, Commissioner, how much the European railway sector is likely to benefit from this growth pact?
Madam President, we are going to have a debate on ACTA tomorrow, but I would like to deal tonight with a peripheral but extremely important question on this subject.
These are the words spoken by Commissioner De Gucht in the Committee on International Trade on Wednesday 20 June.

If you decide to vote against it before the European Court of Justice has ruled, let me tell you that the Commission will nevertheless continue to pursue the current procedure before the Court of Justice.
We are committed to it.
A negative vote will not stop the proceedings before the Court of Justice.

Not only do these words seem to me to be unconvincing of the Treaties, but above all, and this is what I want to denounce, they show an unacceptable contempt for the European Parliament, for democracy in general and for the citizens we represent.
This is the time when European citizens as a whole
Mr President, at this hour many things have been said.
Commissioner, I would like to thank you very warmly.
Thanks to your stubbornness and your procedural tricks, you are enabling us to prove the importance of the European Parliament as a co-legislator.
Thank you, Commissioner, for pushing hundreds of thousands of citizens to take to the streets and for two million to sign petitions.
They have discovered that democracy is at stake here, that our elected representatives in Europe are the representatives of the people, their representatives.
Thank you again for the millions of Internet users who have followed the debates and votes in the committees and who are still following us today.
I welcome them, it is a fresh air in our institutions, too often perceived as technocratic.
Mr President, Commissioner, but in a democracy it is also another principle.
It is the fundamental principle of responsibility.
Tomorrow we will take responsibility, and I would also like to thank you for taking responsibility for your failure, the failure of your working method.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking on behalf of Maurice Ponga, rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Development on Mr Gallagher's report.
It seems important to me to recall that when it comes to sanctioning a country that practices unsustainable fishing, it must take account of its level of development.

In fact, in the name of the principle of policy coherence with the development objectives, it is crucial, in my view, that the measures adopted in the field of fisheries do not call into question the development plans and strategies put in place by the European Union in these countries.
Mr Gallagher's draft report takes up this important idea for our Committee on Development, by providing that the measures must not be unjustified or even discriminatory.

I therefore call on the European Commission, when it takes such measures, to respect this principle of policy coherence with the development objectives and to take due account of the level of development and the vulnerability of countries.
The third reform of the common fisheries policy must not be repeated against the interests of fishermen.

No, not all fishermen are these sea-thieves, the only ones responsible for the poor health of the stocks, as they claim, by including all categories of fish, environmental organisations and the European Commission.

Of course, we must preserve fish stocks, but we must also allow our fishermen to make a living from their activities and preserve the economic fabric, dynamism and cultural identity of our coastal regions.
However, the main measures taken by the European executive are once again aimed at reducing the number of fishermen in order to achieve the mythical maximum sustainable yield.
I would remind you that the French fleet has decreased by more than 50 since 1980.

The Commission proposes, in particular, the introduction of transferable individual quotas, which guarantee industrialisation and the concentration of the sector, or the total prohibition of discards, which professionals consider unrealistic.
This reform project is probably suitable for the industrial fleet, but in the current state it would mean the planned death of what remains of local and artisanal fishing.

Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate the EPP rapporteur, our colleague Mr Karins, on this difficult report, given the sensitivity of bilateral energy negotiations between European countries and third countries.
The agreement reached in trilogue will allow the Commission's draft decision to be implemented quickly, and for the sake of pragmatism we can only rejoice.
Energy Europe is progressing, not fast enough, of course, but it is progressing.
The European Union, which is a major importer of energy, is structurally dependent on certain supplier countries.

In order to have a more European reflection on our energy strategy, it had become necessary to disseminate more widely to the European Commission the information relating to energy agreements while respecting the principle of subsidiarity.
The establishment of an information mechanism on intergovernmental agreements will therefore improve transparency on the energy market and thus help to anticipate energy supply problems.
I welcome the fact that this decision does not create an obligation with regard to agreements between trading companies.
In times of crisis and given the challenges of competition and competitiveness, we had to protect the interests of our companies and the rules for the protection of private contracts.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank our two rapporteurs for their work on this matter.

It was necessary, because we were going very far with the Commission's basic proposal, no specific mention of the outermost regions directly concerned by the competition of the countries of Latin America, no automatic triggering.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not been able to reach an agreement with the Council on this matter, and if so, what is the Commission's position?
That is why it is extremely important that tomorrow's vote validates the progress made on these points in the Committee on International Trade.
Nevertheless, this is not enough, because we know that the trigger thresholds for these two regulations are so high that they make these mechanisms practically inapplicable.
In addition, the Commission must provide for an additional financial envelope to support the competitiveness of Community banana production.
Let us bear in mind that many jobs are at stake in these European regions, which already have record unemployment rates.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank Charles Goerens for his excellent report.

We all know that the European Union provides more than half of the world's total public development aid, and yet, as the deadline for the MDGs approaches in 2015, even though some of the targets seem to be reaching their limits, we are still not there.
We must ask ourselves how to improve our aid, to make it more coherent with our trade policy, with our agricultural policy, with our foreign policy.
The future of European development policy must be based on precise, measurable and short- and medium-term commitments.

The economic crisis, climate change, the power of emerging countries, land grabbing, force us to define new priorities, priorities to ensure food security, access to energy resources and access to health care.

Of course, there is a European consensus, but we need to rethink the European and international institutional systems in environmental and social matters, drawing inspiration from decision-making bodies such as the WTO, for example.
Finally, and above all, we must explain to our fellow citizens that the development of third countries is not only charity and solidarity, but also a source of development for us.
Just look at the markets that are opening up for Europeans in emerging countries like China, Brazil and India.
2015 will also be an opportunity to take better account of the geostrategic developments of recent years, as today's emerging countries were only recently developing countries.
Now, as an indispensable economic power, these countries must also contribute to international aid.
The European Union must be the promoter of responsible development aid at European and international level.

2015 will be more than a deadline, it will be a unique opportunity to rethink development aid, not just as financial assistance, but as support for responsible development projects, both at social and environmental level.

I therefore join my colleagues from the other groups and those from the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions in calling for 2015 to be designated the European Year of Development and, above all, a Year of Responsible Development.
Mr President, the agenda for change proposed by the Commission raises, in my view, many questions, the main one being the concrete implementation of the principle of differentiation.

The Commission hopes that, from 2014, the choice of countries in which the European Union will invest its development aid will be based on the mechanical application of the simple criterion of wealth per capita.
As Mrs Ashton has pointed out, these issues are not only of an accounting nature, but deserve a genuine political debate on the definition of our priorities for international cooperation.
Moreover, this differentiated approach is not, in my view, in line with the spirit of the Cotonou Agreement.
I am convinced that ACP countries which have achieved positive economic performance should be encouraged in their transition towards more sustainable growth.
Madam President, Commissioner, let us welcome the initiative taken by Jacques Delors 20 years ago, at the very moment when the Berlin Wall was falling.
Nevertheless, despite all the progress we have made since the beginning of our debate, it is clear that the Single Act is now synonymous with injustice, inequality and economic liberalism.
So I would like to hear you, Mr Barnier, Commissioner, tell us how we are going to build together a fairer Europe, a Europe that facilitates, a Europe that protects.
There are a number of tracks, and I would like to hear from you, that are at the heart of the economic and social crisis, such as, unfortunately, we know, fiscal harmonization, public services.
Protecting minimum wages in Europe, establishing enhanced cooperation, creating jobs, facilitating cross-border cooperation and developing a fair trade policy.
These are the issues, I believe, twenty years later, that are before us.
I am counting on you, Commissioner, to bring us together on this beautiful policy of European construction.

Mr President, as a member of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, I took a close interest in the report by my colleague, Regina Bastos, on the twenty main issues of concern to citizens and businesses.
We have debated this report in connection with our debate on the 20th anniversary of the internal market.
It has already been twenty years since the free movement of goods, people, services and capital was supposed to be fully exercised within our living, trading and internal market space.

I was particularly interested in the fact that the first priority of the requests made by our European citizens is the essence of professional qualifications and that we really need to be particularly proactive and particularly efficient.

This is what our citizens are really waiting for in order to be able to set up, in the very near future, procedures for the recognition of their qualifications, skills and qualifications, which are really faster, simpler, more efficient and less costly.
It's a real game.

As the EPP Group's fictitious rapporteur on the modernisation of these procedures, I am actively working with the other members of the IMCO Committee to truly respond to this major challenge of mobility.
For more mobility, for more Europe, that is what our fellow citizens are asking for.
Mr President, this year the Committee on Petitions has acquired the right to be automatically associated with the hearing of European citizens' initiatives.
For me, this is the strong signal of 2011 for this Commission.
Citizens already had a Commission to which they could turn in case of non-compliance with their rights, but this is also the case now that they will have proposals to improve European legislation.
I hope that the Committee on Petitions will thus be able to be regarded more and more often as the privileged interlocutor of citizens in the European Parliament.
This problem of consideration is also reflected in the results of the Committee on Petitions' positions.
Too often we are called upon by citizens who are faced with legal ambiguities on which we would like to take a position, but when the problems are European,
Even though the solutions should be European, we remain powerless because subsidiarity does not always go hand in hand with European solutions for lack of national will.

Mr President, I will take the difficult example of transnational divorces, where the problems are both national and European when the rights of custody or visitation go beyond the national borders, namely those of Germany.
Despite the obvious difficulties for many parents to see their children born of a binational union, we in Parliament are still powerless to act.

My proposal that all European citizens should have the right to a national mediator, especially from Germany, which sends an enormous number of petitions on the model of the human rights defender in France, has not been followed with any effect.
However, in the case of transnational divorces, this remains a conciliatory solution, a European problem and a national solution.
In many cases, European law seems powerless to meet the expectations of citizens.
The European Year of Citizens 2013 will have to deal with the grievances of citizens, the costs, but we need the means to act to be
